title: James Academy v. Dorchester County School District Two
description: This case involves the conditional approval of a charter school.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				James Academy of Excellence, Respondent,
				v.
				Dorchester County School District Two, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Dorchester County
James C. Williams, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26428
Submitted December 6, 2007 - Filed February 4, 2008Â  

REVERSED  


	
		
			
				Alice F. Paylor, of Rosen, Rosen & Hagood, LLC, of Charleston; and Arnold S. Goodstein, of Goodstein Law Firm, of Summerville, for appellant.
				Respondent pro se.
			
		
	


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  This appeal
  is from a circuit court order regarding appellant Dorchester County School
  District Twoâ€™s (Districtâ€™s) conditional approval of a charter school
  application.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Respondent James Academy of Excellence (Academy) applied to District for a charter school to open in the 2004-2005
  school year for 300 students in grades six through twelve.Â  On August 11, 2003,
  Districtâ€™s Board of Trustees voted to give â€œconditional approval to the school
  contingent upon the school finding a site in [District].â€Â   
On May 4, Academy advised District that it had
  located a site for the school on Dorchester Road.Â  District made two payments
  of $43,855.63 to Academy on July 16 and July 30 based on Academyâ€™s student enrollment.[1]Â 
  Academy subsequently decided to use a different site on Landmark Drive instead
  of Dorchester Road and retained an architect for building repairs.Â  On July 16,
  the State Department of Education (State Department) approved plans for the
  building and gave permission to take bids on work to be done.Â   
Districtâ€™s public schools opened on
  August 9.Â  Academy advised District it was not ready to open.Â  On August 12,
  Districtâ€™s assistant superintendent went to Academyâ€™s facility.Â  There was no
  equipment in the school and the school was not operational although Academyâ€™s
  representative said they were â€œhoping to open at any time.â€Â  On August 16, the
  assistant superintendent again went to visit the school and was re-directed to
  the Heritage Trust Building where Academy had found a temporary location.Â  When
  District reported to State Department that Academy was operating in a different
  building than the one submitted for approval, State Department directed
  District to close the school.Â   
On August 17, Districtâ€™s
  superintendent went to Academyâ€™s temporary location at the Heritage Trust Building and delivered a letter stating that because Academy had not met the
  conditions of approval for the charter school, there was no contract with
  District and Academy was therefore not authorized to operate a charter school.Â 
  Academy was directed to inform parents to enroll their students in other
  schools.Â  District also demanded a refund of the $87,711.26 it had given
  Academy to fund the school.Â   
Academyâ€™s Landmark Drive site subsequently
  received a conditional certificate of occupancy from the Office of School
  Facilities on August 23 and the school began holding classes there on that
  date.Â  On September 21, Districtâ€™s Board of Trustees (District Board) held an
  administrative hearing to determine the status of Academyâ€™s school.Â  District
  Board determined that Academy had not met four conditions for approvalâ€”space,
  facility, equipment, and personnelâ€”and therefore no charter contract existed
  with District; however, the board decided to allow Academy until September 28,
  2004, to comply with these conditions.Â   
Academy did not meet the
  conditions for approval as directed by the District Board and instead filed an
  appeal with the State Board of Education (State Board).Â  Academy also demanded
  from District charter school funding that District had withheld.Â   
The State Board ruled that
  Academyâ€™s application had been conditionally approved for a charter school with
  only one conditionâ€”an appropriate facilityâ€”and not the four conditions noted by
  the District Board.Â  The State Board concluded that Academy had not met the
  facility condition because the schoolâ€™s facility did not meet the description
  in Academyâ€™s application for a charter school.Â  The State Board therefore
  affirmed the District Boardâ€™s decision.Â   
On appeal, the circuit court
  concluded that Districtâ€™s conditional approval of Academyâ€™s application did not
  specify that the deadline for compliance was the opening of school.Â  Further,
  when Academy started operating as a school on August 16, it â€œacquired rights
  that triggered the due process provisions of Â§ 59-40-110.â€Â  The court concluded
  these due process rights were violated when the superintendent notified Academy
  on August 17 that it could not operate as a charter school.Â  Finally, the court
  ruled that the facility description set forth in Academyâ€™s application was not
  the standard to determine whether Academy had met the condition for an
  appropriate site.Â  The State Boardâ€™s decision finding no charter school
  contract was therefore reversed.Â   
The circuit court subsequently held
  an evidentiary hearing and determined that Academy was entitled to damages
  amounting to $259,821.90 for rent reimbursement and student stipends from
  District.Â  District appeals.
ISSUES

	1.  Was there a
  due process violation?
	2.  Did a
  contract for a charter school exist?
	3.  Were
  damages properly awarded?

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Due process
The circuit court found Academy had
  acquired â€œcertain rightsâ€ under the conditional charter it received from
  District and therefore Academy was entitled to notice and a hearing before its
  status as a charter school could be terminated.Â  The court concluded Academyâ€™s
  due process rights had been violated.Â  District contends this was error.Â  We agree.
First, the Charter School Act specifically
  provides that no rights accrue from a conditional charter.Â  As stated in S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 59-40-80 (2004):[2] 
 

	Â§ 59-40-80. Conditional
  authorization of charter school.
	A sponsor may
  conditionally authorize a charter school before the applicant has secured its
  space, equipment, facilities, and personnel if the applicant indicates such
  authority is necessary for it to meet the requirements of this chapter.Â  Conditional
    authorization does not give rise to any equitable or other claims based on reliance,
    notwithstanding any promise, parole (sic), written, or otherwise,
      contained in the authorization or acceptance of it, whether preceding or
      following the conditional authorization.

(emphasis added).Â  Under this provision, Academy acquired no
  rights based on its conditional charter.Â  This provision ensures that the local
  school district maintains control during the approval process while allowing a
  prospective charter school to receive funding and proceed in setting up its
  operation.  
The interests protected by the Due
  Process Clause are defined not by the constitution but by independent sources
  such as state law.Â  Lexington County Sch. Dist. One Bd. of
    Trustees v. Boost, 282 S.C. 32, 316 S.E.2d 677 (1984) (citing Board
      of Regents v. Roth, 408 U.S. 564 (1972)).Â  Here, state law provides that
  the conditional authorization of a charter school creates no rights in the
  applicant.Â  Accordingly, there are no due process rights implicated in the
  termination of a conditional charter.  
Moreover, any lack of due process was remedied by
  the evidentiary hearing before the District Board when the District Board gave
  Academy additional time to comply.Â  See Ross v. Med. Univ. of South Carolina, 328 S.C.51, 492 S.E.2d 62 (1997) (state may cure procedural
  deprivation of due process rights by later procedural remedy).Â  In conclusion,
  there was no deprivation of due process and the circuit court erred in so
  finding.Â   
2.Â 
  Conditions for approval
The circuit court found that the
  facility description in Academyâ€™s application was not the standard to determine
  if Academy had complied with the facility requirement.Â  The court held it was
  â€œarbitrary and capriciousâ€ to hold Academy to the terms of its application
  which was â€œcompleted many months prior to the schoolâ€™s opening [when] there
  were many unknown variablesâ€¦.â€Â  The circuit court found a binding charter
  existed.Â  District contends this was error.Â  We agree.
The Charter School Act provides
  that â€œthe charter school application shall be a proposed contractâ€ and
  it must include certain terms, including a description of the facility.Â  S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 59-40-60(F)(10) (2004) (emphasis added).Â  The terms of an approved
  charter application become the terms of the agreement between the parties. Â§ 59-40-60(A).Â  A material revision of the terms of the
  agreement requires the approval of both parties.Â  Â§ 59-40-60(C).
This statutory language clearly
  envisions the charter schoolâ€™s fulfillment of the terms of its application as a
  contractual obligation.Â  Â Â Here, Academy never sought to amend its
  application.Â  It is uncontested that Academyâ€™s facility did not meet the terms
  set forth in Academyâ€™s application and the facility was never approved by
  District.Â  The application described a facility with approximately 25,000
  square feet, a minimum of fourteen classrooms, a science lab, computer lab,
  cafeteria, administration offices, a main office, a multi-purpose room, and
  restrooms.Â  Academyâ€™s facility is 6,700 square feet and has none of the
  requisite rooms except for restrooms.Â   
We find the circuit court erred in
  ignoring the requirements of the Charter School Act and ruling that Academy was
  not required to meet the terms set forth in its application.Â  Under the Charter
  School Act, no charter existed and Academy was not operating as a charter
  school.
3.Â 
  Damages hearing
After finding a binding contract,
  the circuit court held an evidentiary hearing over Districtâ€™s objection and
  awarded damages to Academy.Â  District contends the circuit court had no
  authority to hold a hearing on damages while sitting as an appellate court in
  this administrative appeal.Â  We agree.Â  The circuit court heard this case on
  appeal from the State Board, a state agency.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-310(2) (2005) (â€œAgencyâ€ means each state board).Â  Review of a state agency
  decision is confined to the record.Â  Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (2005).[3]Â 
  The circuit court clearly exceeded its authority in holding an evidentiary
  hearing on the issue of damages.
Moreover, as discussed above, a contract for a
  charter school did not exist.Â  Damages should not have been awarded since
  District was not obligated to fund the school.Â  Accordingly, the decision of
  the circuit court is  
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY, JJ.,
  concur.

[1] Academy also received a $20,000 planning grant and a
  $200,000 start-up grant from the State Department of Education to fund the
  school.
[2] The Charter School Act was subsequently amended in
  2006.Â  This section has remained substantially the same.  
[3] This section was subsequently amended in 2006 and the
  subsection was re-numbered.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Donna Moore, Respondent
				v.
				Lance Moore,
      Jr., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Jocelyn B. Cate, Family Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26429
Heard November 15, 2007 - Filed February
  11, 2008 
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				Gregory
  Samuel Forman, of Charleston, and Norbert E. Cummings, Jr., of Cummings Law
  Firm, of Summerville, for Appellant.
				Anthony
  P. LaMantia, III, Allison J. LaMantia, of LaMantia Law Firm, and Mary Kathryn
  Schmutz, all of Charleston, for Respondent.
				Assistant
  Attorney General Warren V. Ganjehsani, of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae. 
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  In this direct appeal, Lance
  Moore, Jr. (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s decision entering an Order of
  Protection from domestic abuse in favor of Donna Moore (Wife).Â  Husband
  challenges the courtâ€™s decision and underlying statutory authority based on due
  process and equal protection grounds. We affirm as modified.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On October 1, 2006,
  officers with the Mount Pleasant Police Department were summoned to the Mooresâ€™ home after 911 personnel received a call from the Mooresâ€™ fifteen-year-old son.Â 
  The partiesâ€™ son reported that Husband had become physically abusive with him
  and his mother and threatened them with a weapon.Â  Police arrested Husband and
  charged him with criminal domestic violence (CDV).Â  The next day, Husband was
  released on bond and ordered not to go near the Mooresâ€™ residence.Â  Â According
  to Wife, Husband drove by the residence and at one point entered the yard to
  remove several items.Â  On October 3, 2006, Wife filed an action pursuant to
  section 20-4-50[1] of the
  â€œProtection from Domestic Abuse Actâ€ (the Act) requesting an emergency hearing
  and an Order of Protection against Husband.Â  At 7:50 p.m. on October 4, 2006,
  Husband was served in Sumter with a summons to appear for an emergency hearing
  scheduled for 9:00 a.m. on October 5, 2006, in Charleston.
At the hearing,
  Husband and Wife both appeared without counsel.Â  Initially, the family court
  judge inquired whether Wife wanted a continuance in order to obtain counsel.Â 
  Wife declined, stating that she wanted to obtain an immediate restraining order
  against Husband.Â  When Husband requested a continuance so that he could obtain
  counsel, the judge denied the request, and stated â€œ[t]his is an Emergency
  Hearing, [Wife] doesnâ€™t want to continue this case, we got to go forward
  today.â€Â  Throughout the proceeding, Husband reluctantly responded to the
  judgeâ€™s questions and indicated that he did not want to proceed without the
  assistance of counsel.Â  
After
  hearing Wifeâ€™s testimony and questioning the parties, the judge found Husband
  had abused Wife and their son.Â  As a result, the judge issued an Order of
  Protection which, inter alia:Â  restrained Husband from committing any
  further abuse or from having any contact with Wife and the partiesâ€™ two minor
  children; awarded Wife temporary custody of the partiesâ€™ children; ordered
  Husband to pay temporary child and spousal support; and awarded Wife temporary
  possession of the marital home.Â  In addition to ordering CDV counseling and
  invoking the assistance of the Department of Social Services for the minor
  children, the judge also ordered Husband to relinquish any weapons in his
  possession to the Charleston County Sheriffâ€™s Department until further order of
  the family court. 
On October 13,
  2006, Husband, who was then represented by counsel, filed a motion for
  reconsideration.Â  The family court judge held a hearing on the motion.Â  At the
  hearing, Husbandâ€™s counsel alleged the issuance of the order violated due
  process and denied him equal protection based on the following grounds:Â  (1)
  Husband did not receive â€œample notice and an opportunity to answer [Wifeâ€™s]
  chargesâ€ with the assistance of counsel; and (2) Husbandâ€™s request for a
  continuance was denied whereas Wife was offered a continuance to retain
  counsel.Â  In making these arguments, Husbandâ€™s counsel claimed the order,
  specifically the finding of physical abuse, was a final order which could have
  future ramifications on Husbandâ€™s employment and his right to possess weapons.Â 
  Husband also characterized the proceeding under section 20-4-50(a) as
  â€œquasi-criminalâ€ because â€œit takes away any citizenâ€™s rights without due
  process without a full trial.â€ Â Based on these arguments, Husbandâ€™s counsel
  requested a full hearing on the merits.Â  Counsel, however, recognized that a
  Temporary Restraining Order could be granted to protect Wife until a final
  resolution was reached on all of the issues.Â  
By order dated
  December 15, 2006, the family court denied Husbandâ€™s motion for
  reconsideration.Â  The court found Husbandâ€™s due process rights were not
  violated by the short-time frame preceding the emergency hearing given the
  statute specifically permitted the court to conduct the hearing within
  twenty-four hours after Wifeâ€™s petition was served.Â  Additionally, the court
  held the denial of Husbandâ€™s motion for a continuance did not violate due
  process because the statute was intended to protect the alleged victim of
  domestic abuse.Â  Because Wife chose to proceed with the hearing, the court
  believed that allowing Husband to delay the hearing â€œwould defeat the clear
  legislative intent of the statute which is to provide alleged victims of abuse
  immediate access to the Court for orders of protection.â€Â  Finally, the court
  found Husbandâ€™s equal protection claim to be without merit.Â  Relying on the
  terms of the statute, the court found the â€œAct affords protection for males,
  females and minor children alike.â€Â  The court believed that the emergency
  hearing would not have been conducted differently â€œif the sexes of the parties
  were switched.â€Â  Subsequently, Husband filed this appeal.
I.  DUE PROCESS
Husband
  challenges the issuance of the family courtâ€™s order on two due process
  grounds.Â  Given the permanency and collateral consequences inherent in a
  finding of physical abuse, Husband first contends the provision of section
  20-4-50 which permits a hearing within twenty-four hours of the service of the
  petition violates due process.Â  As a second ground, Husband asserts the family
  courtâ€™s denial of his motion for a continuance constituted an abuse of
  discretion and violated his right to due process.Â  Specifically, he claims the
  short notice and denial of a continuance prohibited him from procuring counsel.
Although
  Husband does not differentiate in his argument between substantive and
  procedural due process, we believe both are implicated in the issues he raises
  on appeal.Â  Accordingly, both are addressed in our analysis.
No
  person shall be deprived of life, liberty, or property without due process of
  law.Â  U.S. Const. amend. XIV, Â§ 1; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 3.Â  â€œIn order to prove
  a denial of substantive due process, a party must show that he was arbitrarily
  and capriciously deprived of a cognizable property interest rooted in state
  law.â€Â  Sloan v. S.C. Bd. of
    Physical Therapy Examâ€™rs,
  370 S.C. 452, 483, 636 S.E.2d 598, 614 (2006); see Mathews v.
    Eldridge, 424 U.S. 319, 332 (1976) (recognizing that before due process
  guarantees are implicated, there must be a deprivation by the government of
  constitutionally protected interest).
Procedural â€œ[d]ue process requires (1) adequate notice; (2) adequate opportunity for a hearing; (3) the right
  to introduce evidence; and (4) the right to confront and cross-examine
  witnesses.â€Â  Clear Channel Outdoor v. City of Myrtle Beach, 372 S.C.
  230, 235, 642 S.E.2d 565, 567 (2007).
In Sloan
  v. South Carolina Board of Physical Therapy Examiners, this Court explained:

	Procedural
  due process requirements are not technical; no particular form of procedure is
  necessary.Â  In re Vora, 354 S.C. at 595, 582 S.E.2d at 416.Â  â€œ[D]ue
  process is flexible and calls for such procedural protections as the particular
  situation demands.â€ Wilson, 352 S.C. at 452, 574 S.E.2d at 733 (quoting 
	Morrissey
    v. Brewer, 408 U.S. 471, 481, 92 S. Ct. 2593, 2600, 33 L.Ed.2d 484, 494
  (1972)).Â  The requirements in a particular case depend on the importance of the
  interest involved and the circumstances under which the deprivation may occur.Â  
	S.C. Dept. of Soc. Servs. v. Beeks, 325 S.C. 243, 246, 481 S.E.2d 703,
  705 (1997).

Sloan v. S.C. Bd. of
  Physical Therapy Examâ€™rs,
  370 S.C. 452, 484, 636 S.E.2d 598, 615 (2006).Â  â€œâ€˜Where important decisions
  turn on questions of fact, due process often requires an opportunity to
  confront and cross-examine adverse witnesses.â€™â€ S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v.
    Wilson, 352 S.C. 445, 452, 574 S.E.2d 730, 734 (2002) (quoting Brown v.
      S.C. State Bd. of Educ., 301 S.C. 326, 329, 391 S.E.2d 866, 867 (1990)).
Applying the
  above-outlined analysis to the facts of the instant case, we find Husbandâ€™s
  substantive due process rights were implicated by the proceedings established
  in section 20-4-50.Â  See State ex rel. Williams v. Marsh, 626
  S.W.2d 223, 230 (Mo. 1982)(en banc) (finding property and liberty
  interests of respondent to a petition for order of protection are implicated
  and protection of procedural due process is appropriate).Â  Specifically,
  Husbandâ€™s constitutionally protected liberty and property interests are subject
  to temporary deprivation as a result of the issuance of an Order of
  Protection.Â  Once the order is issued Husband, i.e., a respondent to a
  petition, is subject to:Â  the immediate loss of his children; reduction in his
  financial resources if child/spousal support is ordered; and immediate loss of
  possession of the marital residence.[2]Â  Husband also immediately becomes subject to criminal prosecution
  or contempt proceedings if he violates the Order of Protection.Â  Additionally,
  Husband is required to immediately relinquish any weapons in his possession or
  be subject to federal prosecution pursuant to 18 U.S.C.A. Â§ 922.[3]Â  If Husband is employed in law enforcement, the inability to
  possess a weapon may impact his ability to perform his job.[4]Â  
Significantly, not
  only is Husband subject to immediate deprivation of constitutionally protected
  interests, he may also suffer future ramifications as a consequence of the
  issuance of the Order of Protection.Â  The factual finding of physical abuse may
  have a long-term impact on both marital and civil litigation.Â  In terms of
  marital litigation, a definitive finding of physical abuse could be used by
  Wife in the following respects:Â  a ground for divorce (physical cruelty); the
  award of custody; a fault factor for the award of alimony; and a factor to be
  taken into consideration for the equitable apportionment of the marital
  assets.Â  Furthermore, a factual finding of physical abuse could potentially be
  used in a civil claim by Wife for recovery of actual or punitive damages caused
  by the physical abuse.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-130 (1985)(â€œAny
  proceeding under [the chapter regarding the protection from domestic abuse] is
  in addition to other civil and criminal remedies.â€). Â Because Husbandâ€™s
  constitutionally protected interests in liberty and property are implicated by
  the issuance of the Order of Protection, procedural due process protection
  should be afforded to Husband, i.e., a respondent to a petition.Â  
Although
  due process protection is applicable in this situation, it is not without
  limitation. Â Nor are a respondentâ€™s interests paramount to the Stateâ€™s interest
  in protecting a petitioner or other household members from domestic abuse.Â  In
  view of these competing interests, it is necessary for this Court to balance these
  interests to determine the extent and nature of applicable due process
  procedures.Â  See Arnett v. Kennedy, 416 U.S. 134, 167-68 (1974) (noting extent and nature of due process procedures depends upon weighing
  of the private interests affected and the related government functions).Â  In doing
  so, we are guided by the intent of the Legislature in promulgating the Act,
  particularly section 20-4-50.Â  

	Commentators
  have observed:
	The Protection from Domestic Abuse Act was enacted to deal with
  the problem of abuse between family members.Â  The effect of the Act was to
  bring the parties before a judge as quickly as possible to prevent further
  violence.Â  Speedy access to the courts also [minimizes] the disruption to any
  children of the parties since the family court may order payment of temporary
  financial support.Â  By expediting the provision of child support, the Act helps
  prevent the abused spouse from returning to her abuser based on financial
  reasons.

17 S.C. Jur. Criminal
  Domestic Violence, Â§ 14 (Supp. 2007).Â  
We agree
  with this commentary, and believe the Legislature properly effectuated the
  above goal by creating a statutory scheme that permits expedited proceedings
  within twenty-four hours from service of the petition before either the family
  court or, if necessary, before a magistrate who may grant a limited temporary
  restraining order.Â  See S.C. Code Â§ 20-4-30(A) (Supp. 2006) (â€œThe family
  court has jurisdiction over all proceedings under this chapter except that,
  during nonbusiness hours or at other times when the court is not in session,
  the petition may be filed with a magistrate. Â The magistrate may issue an order
  of protection granting only the relief provided by Section 20-4-60(a)(1).â€).Â  
Furthermore,
  by providing a respondent with notice of a petition prior to the hearing and an
  opportunity to be heard, section 20-4-20 complies with the requisite procedural
  due process guarantees.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-20(f) (Supp. 2006)
  (â€œâ€˜Order of protectionâ€™ means an order of protection issued to protect the
  petitioner or minor household members from the abuse of another household
  member where the respondent has received notice of the proceedings and has
    an opportunity to be heard.â€)(emphasis added).Â  Here, Husband was provided
  notice of the hearing and given an opportunity to actively participate in terms
  of questioning Wife and answering the courtâ€™s questions.Â  Husband, however,
  chose not to participate in the hearing and, thus, failed to take advantage of
  the procedural safeguards established by the Act.Â  
Additionally,
  given that relief awarded in an Order of Protection is temporary and
  potentially modifiable, the procedure established by the Legislature is
  sufficient to comply with procedural due process.Â  Finally, as evident in this
  case, a respondent may obtain counsel after the hearing in order to move for
  reconsideration or seek modification of certain relief awarded to petitioner.Â  See State ex rel. Williams v. Marsh, 626 S.W.2d 223, 230 (MO 1982)(en banc) (â€œNotice and an opportunity to be heard must be provided by the
  state in a meaningful manner prior to deprivation of a protected interest.Â 
  This rule is not necessarily applied when there is a temporary taking, as is
  the case here.Â  Due process is a flexible concept.â€) (citations omitted); see
    also State v. Doe, 765 A.2d 518, 523-29 (Conn. Super. Ct. 2000) (concluding defendant had not been prejudiced by issuance of initial protective
  order without an attorney where he had the order modified with the aid of
  counsel).Â  
Notably, appellate
  courts from other jurisdictions have held that statutes similar to this stateâ€™s
  Protection from Domestic Abuse Act are not violative of due process.Â  See,
    e.g., Paschal v. Hazlinsky, 803 So. 2d 413, 417-19 (La. Ct. App.
  2001) (holding no due process violation with respect to hearings for protective
  orders against domestic abuse); Kampf v. Kampf, 603 N.W.2d 295, 299
  (Mich. Ct. App. 1999) (concluding Wifeâ€™s obtaining personal protection order
  without notice to Husband did not violate his procedural due process rights); Baker
    v. Baker, 494 N.W.2d 282, 288-89 n.9 (Minn. 1992), superseded in part by
      statute in Burkstrand v. Burkstrand, 632 N.W.2d 206 (Minn. 2001)
  (relying on guidance of cases from other jurisdictions and finding ex parte
  procedures of Domestic Abuse Act comply with applicable rules as well as due
  process); Schramek v. Bohren, 429 N.W.2d 501, 503-05 (Wisc. Ct. App.
  1988) (finding spousal abuse statute was not unconstitutional).
Even
  though Husbandâ€™s procedural due process rights were not violated by the
  short-time period between service of the petition and the hearing or Husbandâ€™s
  inability to procure counsel for the emergency hearing, we are concerned that a
  factual finding of physical abuse was finally adjudicated at this emergency
  hearing.Â  
Without
  question, the immediate protection of potential victims from domestic abuse is
  a legitimate government interest which requires a prompt hearing and issuance
  of a temporary order if the evidence necessitates.Â  However, we believe a definitive
  factual finding of physical abuse for a temporary Order of Protection is not
  only improper under the terms of the statute, but is also unnecessary to
  satisfy the governmentâ€™s interest.Â  In our view, the Legislature provided for
  an emergency hearing, for the benefit of victims of domestic violence and did
  not intend for these protections to establish collateral consequences for the
  alleged abuser.Â  Cf. State v. Dispoto, 913 A.2d 791, 798
  (N.J. 2007) (stating â€œthe remedial protections afforded under the [New Jersey
  Protection of Domestic Violence Act] are intended for the benefit of victims of
  domestic violence and are not meant to serve as a pretext for obtaining
  information to advance a criminal investigation against an alleged abuserâ€).Â 
  Instead, we believe the Legislature intended for the findings, which result
  from an emergency hearing pursuant to section 20-4-50(a), to be temporary and
  confined to the Order of Protection.Â  Implicit in this conclusion is that these
  findings cannot be used in future litigation unless they are confirmed in a
  subsequent hearing on the merits.
In
  reaching this conclusion, we need look no further than the terms of the Act.Â  See Beattie v. Aiken County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 319 S.C. 449, 452, 462
  S.E.2d 276, 278 (1995) (recognizing that in interpreting a statute, our primary
  purpose is to ascertain the intent of the Legislature); Id. (â€œâ€˜A statute as a whole must receive a
  practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation consonant with the purpose,
  design, and policy of the lawmakers.â€™â€ (quoting Browning v. Hartvigsen,
  307 S.C. 122, 125, 414 S.E.2d 115, 117 (1992))).Â  Specifically, we focus our
  analysis on the procedural prerequisites for petitioning for an emergency
  hearing as well as the proof required for the issuance of an Order of
  Protection.
In
  terms of procedure, it is significant to note that the Petition for an Order of
  Protection â€œmust inform the respondent of the right to retain counsel.â€Â  S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-40(c) (Supp. 2006).Â  We interpret this requirement to mean
  that the Legislature intended for a respondent to have a meaningful opportunity
  to retain counsel in order to participate in a hearing conducted pursuant to
  the Act.Â  Because section 20-4-50(a) authorizes a family court to conduct an
  emergency hearing â€œ[w]ithin twenty-four hours after service of a petition,â€ it
  would be nonsensical to believe that a respondent would be able to retain
  counsel and prepare for an adjudicative hearing within such a limited time
  frame.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-50(a) (Supp. 2006).Â  A strict reading of this
  statutory provision would mean that an emergency hearing could be conducted
  within mere hours of when a respondent was served with the petition.Â  Clearly,
  we do not believe the Legislature intended for this result.Â  
Furthermore,
  we glean additional support for our interpretation by comparing a related
  provision of section 20-4-50 with the above-quoted provision.Â  Subsection (b)
  of this statute provides:

	If the court denies the motion for a twenty-four-hour hearing or
  such a hearing is not requested, the petitioner may request and the court must
  grant a hearing within fifteen days of the filing of a petition.Â  The court
  must cause a copy of the petition to be served upon the respondent at least five
  days prior to the hearing, except as provided in subsection (a), in the same
  manner required for service in the circuit courts.Â  Where service is not
  accomplished five days prior to the hearing, the respondent, upon his motion,
  is entitled to a continuance until such time is necessary to provide for
  compliance with this section.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-50(b)
  (Supp. 2006).Â Â  The significant difference between the procedures employed in
  each of the subsections is that the respondent is given a minimum of five days
  to obtain counsel and prepare for the hearing and may be granted a continuance
  if the five days are not provided under subsection (b), whereas there is no
  mention of a continuance if an emergency hearing is conducted under subsection
  (a).Â  Â Given that a respondent is not given a meaningful opportunity to retain
  counsel and prepare if a twenty-four-hour emergency hearing is requested and
  conducted, we conclude the Legislature intended for the emergency hearing to be
  temporary in nature.Â  Inferentially, a hearing conducted pursuant to section
  20-4-50(b), which provides a respondent an extended period of time in which to
  retain counsel and prepare his or her case, should be viewed as an adjudicative
  hearing on the merits of the action.
A
  review of the proof required for the issuance of an Order of Protection
  solidifies our conclusion that an order issued pursuant to a twenty-four-hour
  emergency hearing is intended to be temporary and not a final determination.Â  For
  a court to issue an Order of Protection after an emergency hearing, a
  petitioner must prove â€œthe allegation of abuse by a preponderance of the
  evidence.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-50(a)(Supp. 2006).Â  The statute further provides
  that â€œ[a] prima facie showing of immediate and present danger of bodily injury,
  which may be verified by supporting affidavits, constitutes good cause for
  purposes of this section.â€Â  Id.Â  A review of these statutory
  prerequisites reveals that a definitive finding of physical abuse is not
  essential.Â  
Although
  the Act defines â€œabuseâ€ to include â€œphysical abuse,â€ â€œbodily injury,â€ and
  â€œassault,â€ it also recognizes that â€œthe threat of physical harmâ€ is sufficient
  to constitute a basis for the issuance of an Order of Protection as the result
  of an emergency hearing.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-20(a)(1) (1985 & Supp.
  2006).Â  Furthermore, in our opinion, a showing of â€œimmediate and present danger
  of bodily injuryâ€ denotes that the threat of a future occurrence provides the
  basis for an Order of Protection and, thus, a definitive finding of physical abuse
  is not mandated.Â  Finally, we note that this type of finding would be
  sufficient to satisfy the provision of 18 U.S.C.A. Â§ 922(g)(8)(C)(i), which
  only requires â€œa finding that such person represents a
  credible threat to the physical safety of such intimate partner or child.â€Â  
Based
  on the foregoing, we hold that an Order of Protection issued pursuant to an
  emergency hearing is temporary and that a hearing on the merits of the action
  should, if necessary, be conducted by the family court at a later date. [5] Â This procedure would then enable a petitioner and a respondent
  to procure counsel in order to actively and thoroughly participate in an
  adjudicative hearing on the merits of the action. [6]
II.  EQUAL PROTECTION
Finally,
  Husband claims the family court engaged in â€œinvidious gender discriminationâ€ by
  denying his motion for a continuance but offering Wife a continuance in order
  to provide her with more time to prepare or seek counsel.
As
  we understand this argument, Husband is primarily challenging the family
  courtâ€™s decision not to grant a continuance as opposed to positing an argument
  that the Act violates the Equal Protection Clause.Â  Thus, this argument is not in
  actuality an equal protection challenge.Â  However, to the extent Husbandâ€™s
  argument can be construed as such a challenge, we find this issue is without
  merit.
The Equal Protection Clauses of our federal
  and state constitutions declare that no person shall be denied the equal protection of the laws.Â  U.S.
  Const. amend. XIV, Â§ 1; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 3.Â  Equal protection requires
  â€œall persons to be treated alike under like circumstances and conditions, both
  in privileges conferred and liabilities imposed.â€Â  GTE Sprint Commcâ€™ns Corp.
    v. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n of South Carolina, 288 S.C. 174, 181, 341 S.E.2d 126,
  129 (1986). Â â€œCourts
  generally analyze equal protection challenges under one of three standards: (1)
  rational basis; (2) intermediate scrutiny; or, (3) strict scrutiny.â€ Denene,
    Inc. v. City of Charleston, 359 S.C. 85, 91, 596 S.E.2d 917, 920 (2004).Â 
  â€œGender-based classifications are not inherently suspect so as to be subject to
  strict scrutiny and will be upheld if they bear a fair and substantial
  relationship to legitimate state ends.â€ In the Interest of Joseph T.,
  312 S.C. 15, 16, 430 S.E.2d 523, 524 (1993).Â  â€œFor a gender-based
  classification to pass constitutional muster, it must serve an important
  governmental objective and be substantially related to the achievement of that
  objective.â€Â  State v. Wright, 349 S.C. 310, 313, 563 S.E.2d 311, 312
  (2002)(citing Craig v. Boren, 429 U.S. 190 (1976)).Â  â€œA law will be
  upheld where the gender classification realistically reflects the fact that the
  sexes are not similarly situated in certain circumstances.â€ Id.
In
  the instant case, the family court judge did not base her decision on gender,
  but rather on the respective posture of the parties, i.e., that Wife was
  the â€œpetitionerâ€ and had the burden of establishing the need for an Order of Protection.Â 
  As defined by section 20-4-20, a â€œâ€˜[p]etitionerâ€™ means the person alleging abuse in a petition for an order of protection.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-4-20(d) (1985) (emphasis added).Â  A review of the quoted text as well the
  rest of the definitional section of the Act, reveals that the statute clearly utilizes
  the word â€œperson,â€ a non-gender specific term, to define the parties to an
  action for an Order of Protection. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-20(b), (d), & (e)
  (1985). Â Thus, there is no gender-based classification that would implicate a
  violation of the Equal Protection Clause.Â  See State v. Doe,
  765 A.2d 518, 523-27 (Conn. Super. Ct. 2000) (holding statutory classification
  of victim and a defendant involved in issuance of a protective order did not
  violate defendantâ€™s equal protection rights).Â  
Furthermore,
  to the extent Husband attacks the family courtâ€™s decision to deny his motion
  for a continuance, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion.Â  See Bridwell v. Bridwell, 279 S.C. 111, 112, 302 S.E.2d 856, 858 (1983)
  (stating the grant or denial of a continuance is within the sound discretion of
  the trial judge and is reviewable on appeal only when an abuse of discretion
  appears from the record).Â  Because, as previously discussed, Husband was
  provided with procedural due process at the hearing, we disagree with Husbandâ€™s
  contention that he was entitled to a continuance.Â  Moreover, Husband
  subsequently retained counsel and was permitted to move for reconsideration of
  the order.Â  Accordingly, Husband was not prejudiced by going forward with the
  emergency hearing. Townsend v. Townsend, 323 S.C. 309, 313, 474 S.E.2d
  424, 427 (1996) (finding appellate court will not set aside a courtâ€™s ruling on
  a motion for a continuance unless it clearly appears there was an abuse of
  discretion to the prejudice of the movant).
CONCLUSION
Because Husband was provided procedural due process prior to the
  issuance of the Order of Protection, we affirm the decision of the family
  court.Â  However, we find that an Order of Protection issued pursuant to an
  emergency hearing is temporary and does not represent a final adjudication of
  the merits of the action.Â  Applying our decision to the instant case, we hold
  the finding of physical abuse was not a final adjudication and, therefore,
  should not be used against Husband in future litigation.Â  Finally, we find
  neither the Act nor the family courtâ€™s decision denying Husband a continuance
  constituted a violation of the Equal Protection Clause.
AFFIRMED AS
  MODIFIED.
MOORE, A.C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., concur.


[1] Â Â Section
  20-4-50 provides:Â   

	a) Within twenty-four
  hours after service of a petition under this chapter upon the respondent, the
  court may, for good cause shown, hold an emergency hearing and issue an order
  of protection if the petitioner proves the allegation of abuse by a
  preponderance of the evidence.Â  A prima facie showing of immediate and present
  danger of bodily injury, which may be verified by supporting affidavits,
  constitutes good cause for purposes of this section.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-4-50(a) (Supp. 2006).
[2]Â Â  Section
  20-4-60 provides in pertinent part:
(c)
  When the court has, after a hearing for any order of protection, issued an
  order of protection, it may, in addition:

	(1)
  Award temporary custody and temporary visitation rights with regard to minor
  children living in the home over whom the parties have custody.
	(2)
  Direct the respondent to pay temporary financial support for the petitioner and
  minor child unless the respondent has no duty to support the petitioner or
  minor child.
	(3) When
  the respondent has a legal duty to support the petitioner or minor children
  living in the household and the householdâ€™s residence is jointly leased or
  owned by the parties or the respondent is the sole owner or lessee, grant temporary
  possession to the petitioner of the residence to the exclusion of the
  respondent.
	(4) Prohibit
  the transferring, destruction, encumbering, or otherwise disposing of real or
  personal property mutually owned or leased by the parties or in which one party
  claims an equitable interest, except when in the ordinary course of business.
	(5) Â Provide
  for temporary possession of the personal property of the parties and order
  assistance from law enforcement officers in removing personal property of the
  petitioner if the respondentâ€™s eviction has not been ordered.
	(6) Â Â Award
  costs and attorneysâ€™ fees to either party.
	(7)Â  Award any other relief authorized by
  Â§ 20-7-420; provided, however, the court must have due regard for any prior
  Family Court orders issued in an action between the parties.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-60(c) (1985 &
  Supp. 2006).

	
	[3]Â Â  The
  pertinent provision of this section provides:Â  
	(g) It shall be unlawful for any
  person--
	(8) who is subject to a court order that--
	(A) was issued
  after a hearing of which such person received actual notice, and at which such
  person had an opportunity to participate;
	(B) restrains such person from harassing,
  stalking, or threatening an intimate partner of such person or child of such
  intimate partner or person, or engaging in other conduct that would place an
  intimate partner in reasonable fear of bodily injury to the partner or child;
  and
	(C)(i) includes a finding that such person
  represents a credible threat to the physical safety of such intimate partner or
  child; or
	(ii) by its terms explicitly prohibits the use, attempted use, or
  threatened use of physical force against such intimate partner or child that
  would reasonably be expected to cause bodily injury; 
	. . .
	to ship or transport in interstate or foreign commerce, or possess
  in or affecting commerce, any firearm or ammunition; or to receive any firearm
  or ammunition which has been shipped or transported in interstate or foreign
  commerce.

18
  U.S.C.A. Â§ 922(g)(8) (2000 & Supp. 2007).Â   
[4]Â Â  See Tom Lininger, A Better Way to Disarm Batterers,
  54 Hastings L.J. 525, 535-48 (2003) (discussing legislative history and
  constitutional challenges to ban of guns while restraining order is in effect
  pursuant to 18 U.S.C. Â§ 922(g)(8)); United States v. Miles, 238 F. Supp.
  2d 297, 300-05 (D. ME 2002) (holding 18 U.S.C.A. Â§ 922(g)(8) passes
  constitutional muster because it is a reasonable restriction on the right to
  bear arms and is narrowly tailored to support a compelling government
  interest); United States v. Calor, 172 F. Supp. 2d 900, 905-07 (E.D. KY 2001) (finding temporary
  deprivation of Husbandâ€™s property right to enjoy firearms during three-day,
  pre-hearing seizure period was outweighed by governmentâ€™s interest in
  protecting victim of domestic violence from further violence and potential
  death); see also Kellogg v. City of Gary, 562 N.E.2d 685, 693
  (Ind. 1990) (discussing due process implications of Second Amendment right to
  bear arms in conjunction with issuance of civil temporary injunction).  
[5]Â  We note that
  if the findings are temporary, a respondent should no longer suffer the
  consequences under the federal statute given a respondent would no longer be
  â€œsubjectâ€ to the court order.Â  18 U.S.C.A. Â§ 922(g)(8) (2000 & Supp. 2007); cf. Weissenburger v. Iowa Dist. Court for Warren County, 740
  N.W.2d 431, 436 (Iowa 2007) (holding that Husband was prohibited from
  possessing firearms pursuant to 18 U.S.C.A. Â§ 922(g)(8) where he was subject to
  a continuing no-contact order with Wife).  
[6] Â Â In light of the problems highlighted by
  this case, we invite the Legislature to revise the Protection from Domestic
  Abuse Act in order to:Â Â  clarify the non-adjudicative nature of the emergency
  hearing; and define the temporary status of an Order of Protection as well as
  the findings associated with the issuance of such an order.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				
				In the Matter of Kelly Christen
      Evans,Â Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26430
Submitted January 11, 2008 - Filed February 11, 2008 

DISBARRED


	
		
			
				Lesley M.
  Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and William C. Campbell, Assistant Disciplinary
  Counsel, both of Columbia, forÂ  Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
				Stephanie
  N. Weissenstein, of Law Offices of Desa A. Ballard, PA, of West Columbia, for
  respondent.Â  
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule
  413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to any
  sanction in Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  She requests that any suspension
  or disbarment be made retroactive to the date of her interim suspension,
  February 26, 2007.Â  In the Matter of Evans, 372 S.C. 254, 642 S.E.2d 578
  (2007).Â  In addition, respondent agrees to pay the costs incurred by ODC and
  the Commission on Lawyer Conduct in investigating this matter. We accept the
  agreement and disbar respondent from the practice of law in this state,
  retroactive to the date of her interim suspension.Â  The facts, as set forth in
  the agreement, are as follows.Â   
FACTS
Respondentâ€™s
  misconduct stems from her failure to understand the business operations of her
  legal practice and her failure to manager her staff.Â  Respondent admits not
  performing monthly reconciliations as required by Rule 417, SCACR, and, as a
  consequence of that failure, having individual client accounts with a shortage
  of funds that went undetected for months.Â   
In particular, respondent
  admits she had several accounts that were short of funds after loans closings.Â 
  In one instance, she permitted a refinance equity line closing to take place
  where the borrower received $150,000.00 in funds although respondent had not
  received the funds from the lender.Â  This error was carried on respondentâ€™s
  account until brought to her attention by her title insurance companyâ€™s audit
  more than one year after the closing.Â  Respondent required seven months to
  recover the funds from the borrower.Â  Respondent admits she failed in her
  responsibilities in this closing.[1]Â  
 
In another loan closing,
  respondent admits she disbursed approximately $21,000.00 without confirming the
  funds had been wired to her account.Â  In this matter, respondent has not
  recovered the funds from the borrower and respondent has replaced the disbursed
  funds with her own personal funds.Â  Respondent admits she carried the resulting
  $21,000.00 deficit in her trust account for approximately two years after the
  closing.Â  Respondent admits she failed in her responsibilities as attorney in
  this closing.Â   
Respondent admits she did
  not understand the financial aspects of her business and, therefore, hired an
  accountant to manage the financial aspects of her practice.Â  While the
  accountant did perform recordkeeping and reconciliations, respondent now
  recognizes that the reconciliations were inaccurate, incomplete, and did not
  come close to meeting the requirements imposed by Rule 417, SCACR.Â  Respondent
  admits she did not review the accountantâ€™s trust account reconciliations.[2]  
Respondent admits that, at
  the time of the initial complaint, she had an outstanding balance due to her
  title insurance company of $60,000.00.Â  Respondent had failed to hold in trust
  the title insurance premiums that were collected by her at closings.Â  Respondentâ€™s
  practice with the title insurance premiums had been to deposit the premiums
  when collected at closings into a bank account titled â€œK.C.E. Title.â€Â 
  Respondent admits that the balance in the K.C.E. Title account was between
  $3,000.00 and $5,000.00 when it should have been sufficient to pay the
  outstanding amount due the title insurance company.Â   
Respondent admits she
  transferred funds from the K.C.E. Title account to bank accounts out of state
  for personal reasons, including payment of her personal mortgage.Â  She states
  the title insurance company has been paid from monies from the out of state
  accounts.Â   
Further, respondent admits
  she wired personal mortgage payments from her trust account on four occasions.Â 
  She claims this was done in error and that she discovered the error a month and
  one half later when she received the bank statement.Â  Respondent admits that
  she did not have any of her own money in the trust account.Â  She states the
  monies have since been paid back to the trust account.Â Â   
Additionally, respondent
  admits she relied on her staff to handle day to day affairs, including office
  accounting and document preparation, and that she did not adequately supervise
  her staff.Â  Respondent permitted staff members to sign her name as attorney to
  closing documents and, at the same time, sign as witness to respondentâ€™s â€œsignature.â€Â  
 
Finally, respondent admits
  she failed to make timely payments to her employeesâ€™ 401K accounts after
  withholding the funds from the employeesâ€™ paychecks.Â  Further, respondent
  admits that she added the funds to the employeesâ€™ 401K accounts in October
  2007, eight months after her interim suspension.Â  Respondent agrees that she
  failed to safeguard her employeesâ€™ funds, some of which were collected from her
  employees in early 2006.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 

LAW
Respondent admits that, by her
  misconduct, she has violated the following provisions of the Rules of
  Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide
  competent representation to a client); Rule 1.3 (lawyer 
shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness
    in representing a client); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall hold
  property of clients and third persons in the lawyerâ€™s possession in connection
  with a representation separate from the lawyerâ€™s own property); Rule 5.3 (partner in a law firm shall make reasonable efforts
    to ensure that the firm has in effect measures giving reasonable assurance that
    a non-lawyer employeeâ€™s conduct is compatible with the professional obligations
    of the lawyer); and Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct
  for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  Â 
Respondent further admits her
  misconduct is grounds for discipline under Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR,
  specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to
  violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  In addition, respondent admits her
  misconduct violated Rule 417, SCACR.Â   

CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline
  by Consent and disbar respondent.Â  The disbarment shall be retroactive to the
  date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  Within thirty (30) days of the date
  of this opinion, respondent shall pay the costs incurred by ODC and the
  Commission on Lawyer Conduct as a result of the investigation in this matter.Â  Within
  fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an
  affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that she has complied with Rule 30 of
  Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender her Certificate of Admission to the
  Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.  
In addition, should it be determined
  that any restitution remains outstanding, ODC and respondent shall file a
  restitution plan with the Court within thirty (30) days of the date of this opinion.Â 
  In the plan, respondent shall agree to pay restitution to all clients, banks,
  and other persons and entities who have incurred losses as a result of her
  misconduct in connection with this matter.Â  Moreover, in the restitution plan,
  respondent shall agree to reimburse the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection for
  any claims paid as a result of her misconduct in connection with this matter.Â 
 
DISBARRED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES
  and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1] Respondent admits that, while she understood the
  HUD-1 Settlement Statement, she did not understand that the funds shown on the
  balance sheet had not been received.Â   
[2] Since her interim suspension, respondent has
  made efforts to have the accounts reconciled and to bring the client accounts
  into balance.Â  It is believed there is a surplus of funds in the accounts at
  this time.Â

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

      Norris,Â Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26431
Submitted January 11, 2008 - Filed February 11, 2008Â Â  

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


	
		
			
				Lesley M.
  Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Joseph P. Turner, Jr., Assistant
  Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				Desa A.
  Ballard, of Law Offices of Desa Ballard, PA, of West Columbia, for respondent.Â 
				
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel
  (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent
  pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits
  misconduct and agrees to issuance of either an admonition or public reprimand.Â 
  We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth
  in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Respondent represented the estate of a
  decedent in a malpractice/wrongful death suit on a contingency basis.Â 
  Respondent contracted for paralegal services and charged the estate $6,300 for
  these services.Â  Respondent believed these services were covered by his
  contract which provided for the client to pay expenses related to litigation.Â 
  When the complainant, an attorney appointed as the personal representative of
  the estate, objected to these fees believing they should have been covered by
  the contingency fee, respondent refunded the total amount to the estate.Â  
The complainant also objected to expert
  bills submitted as part of the settlement statement as he believed these fees
  had been falsified.Â  Respondentâ€™s wife had assisted respondent in preparing the
  settlement statement and had been responsible for collecting these bills.Â 
  Respondent submits that, in investigating the matter, he confronted his wife
  and she admitted falsifying a number of the doctorsâ€™ bills.[1] Respondent acknowledges that he is responsible for the actions of his staff and
  that he should have checked the bills closely before submitting them as part of
  the settlement statement.Â Â Â Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that he has committed
  misconduct in violation of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR,
  particularly Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to
  client), Rule 1.5 (lawyer shall not charge unreasonable amount for expenses;
  contingency fee agreement must set forth expenses to be deducted from
  recovery), and Rule 5.3 (lawyer who possesses supervisory authority over
  non-lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to ensure non-lawyerâ€™s conduct is
  compatible with professional obligations of lawyer and shall be responsible for
  non-lawyerâ€™s conduct if the conduct would be violation of Rules of Professional
  Conduct if engaged in by lawyer).Â  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct
  constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary
  Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for
  discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct
  warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for
  Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES
  and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1] Respondent and his wife have since divorced.Â
