THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				
				Joseph Lowry, Petitioner,
				
				v.
				
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from York County|
Â Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26436
Submitted December 6, 2007 - Filed
  February 11, 2008Â Â   
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Tara
  Shurling, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Julie
  Thames, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In
  this case, the PCR court found that a supplemental jury charge on felony murder
  did not violate Petitionerâ€™s due process rights, and therefore, that Petitionerâ€™s
  counsel was not ineffective in failing to object to the charge.Â  This Court
  granted certiorari to review the PCR courtâ€™s decision.Â  Because we find that
  the charge unconstitutionally shifted the burden of proof for malice in
  Petitionerâ€™s murder conviction, we reverse.
Factual/Procedural
  Background
A
  grand jury indicted Petitioner Joseph Lowry (â€œPetitionerâ€) for murder,
  possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent offense, armed
  robbery, and criminal conspiracy for his role in the September 1994 robbery and
  murder of a motel desk clerk in York County.Â  At trial, the court instructed
  the jury on the elements of each of the charged offenses as well as the laws of
  accomplice liability and criminal intent.Â  The murder charge specifically
  explained the finding of malice beyond a reasonable doubt and addressed
  inferences of malice which may be drawn from certain facts, such as the
  performance of an unlawful act, the use of a deadly weapon, and the commission
  of a felony (known as the felony murder doctrine).Â  With respect to the felony
  murder doctrine, the trial court charged:

	Additionally,
  the law says if one intentionally kills another during the commission of a
  felony, the inference of malice may arise.Â  If facts are proven beyond a
  reasonable doubt sufficient to raise an inference of malice to your
  satisfaction, again I tell you this inference would be simply an evidentiary
  fact to be taken into consideration by you along with the other evidence in
  this case.Â  I charge you that armed robbery with[,] which [Petitioner] is also
  charged[,] is under our state law a felony.

When
  the trial court directed the jury to begin deliberations, the solicitor told
  the court that he had not heard the court charge the felony murder doctrine.Â 
  Although Petitionerâ€™s counsel and the trial court both claimed to have heard such
  an instruction, the trial court ultimately agreed to bring the jurors back in
  for a supplemental instruction on felony murder.Â  In order to alleviate Petitionerâ€™s
  counselâ€™s concern that such a supplemental instruction would highlight the
  theory of felony murder, the trial court stated that it would also incorporate
  aspects of accomplice liability into the charge.  
Upon
  calling the jury back into the courtroom, the trial court gave the following
  charge:

	Let me
  follow up with a very brief instruction regarding what is sometimes referred to
  as the felony murder doctrine.
	The fact
  that I brought you back in is simply because I neglected to charge this.Â  This
  particular charge is not to be given any other weight or highlighted in any way
  by you simply because I brought you in here and gave it to you separate from
  the other. It is my mistake; I left this out, it was called to my attention, and
  I must charge it to you.Â  The fact that it is isolated, you are to give it no
  more consideration.Â  You are to blend it in with the charge as I have given it
  to you.
	. . .
  you will recall I went over and talked with you about accomplice liability, I
  meant to conclude that by telling you this in regard to what is called the
  felony murder doctrine.Â  That is, if a person kills another in the doing or
  attempting to do an act which is considered a felony, the fact that this occurs
  while one is doing or attempting to commit a felony makes the killing murder.Â 
  And, therefore, the killing by one of another in the commission or attempted
  commission of a felony makes that killing, by virtue of it occurring in that
  context[,] a murder.

Petitionerâ€™s counsel did not
  object to the supplemental charge.
The
  jury convicted Petitioner for murder, possession of a firearm during the
  commission of a violent offense, armed robbery, and criminal conspiracy.Â  The
  trial court imposed a life sentence for the murder, concurrent five-year
  sentences for the firearm possession and conspiracy, and a concurrent
  thirty-year sentence for the armed robbery.Â  Following review pursuant to Anders
    v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), this Court affirmed Petitionerâ€™s
  convictions and sentences.Â  State v. Lowry, Op. No. 1998-MO-060 (S.C.
  Sup. Ct. filed July 20, 1998).  
Following
  his direct appeal, Petitioner filed an application for PCR alleging, among
  other things, that trial counsel was ineffective for failing to object to the
  supplemental charge on felony murder.Â  Specifically, Petitioner argued that the
  supplemental instruction was burden-shifting in nature and violated his due
  process rights under the federal and state constitutions by presuming the
  malice element of murder.[1]Â 
  The PCR court found that the supplemental charge, when considered in context
  with the initial jury charge, was fair, and therefore, that counsel was not
  ineffective in failing to object.Â  The PCR court further concluded that the
  charge was not prejudicial given the â€œoverwhelming evidenceâ€ of Petitionerâ€™s
  guilt produced at trial.Â  The PCR court subsequently denied Petitionerâ€™s application.
This
  Court granted certiorari to review Petitionerâ€™s belated appeal from the PCR
  courtâ€™s decision pursuant to Austin v. State, 305 S.C. 453, 409 S.E.2d
  395 (1991) (holding that an applicant has a right to appellate counselâ€™s
  assistance in seeking review of the denial of PCR), and Petitioner raises the
  following issue for review:  

	Was
  counsel ineffective in failing to object to the trial courtâ€™s supplemental jury
  instruction on felony murder because it shifted the burden of proof for malice
  from the State to the Petitioner and deprived Petitioner of due process of
  law?Â Â   

Standard
  of review
In
  reviewing the PCR courtâ€™s decision, an appellate court is concerned only with
  whether any evidence of probative value exists to support that decision.Â  State
    v. Smith, 369 S.C. 135, 138, 631 S.E.2d 260, 261 (2006).Â  If no probative
  evidence exists to support the PCR courtâ€™s findings, this Court will reverse.  Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 145, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000).Â  


Law/Analysis 

Petitioner
  argues that trial counsel was ineffective for failing to object to the courtâ€™s
  supplemental instruction on felony murder.Â  Specifically, Petitioner argues
  that the supplemental charge created a mandatory presumption of malice that
  shifted the burden of proof from the prosecution to the defendant, thereby
  depriving Petitioner of due process of law.Â  We agree.
In
  order to establish a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, Petitioner
  must prove that (1) counsel failed to render reasonably effective assistance
  under prevailing professional norms, and (2) counselâ€™s deficient performance
  prejudiced Petitionerâ€™s case.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 687 (1984); Butler v. State, 286 S.C. 441, 442, 334 S.E.2d 813, 814 (1985).Â 
  A deficient performance by counsel is prejudicial when there is a reasonable
  probability that, but for the counselâ€™s errors, the outcome of the trial would
  have been different.Â  State v. Hill, 350 S.C. 465, 567 S.E.2d 847 (2002)
  (quoting Strickland, 466 U.S. at 687).Â   
Petitionerâ€™s
  claim arises out of the Due Process Clauses of the Fifth and Fourteenth
  Amendments, which protect an accused against conviction unless the State supplies
  proof beyond a reasonable doubt of each element necessary to constitute the
  crime with which the accused is charged.[2]Â  In re Winship, 397 U.S. 358, 364 (1970).Â  This principle prohibits the
  use of evidentiary presumptions in a jury charge that have the effect of
  relieving the State of its burden of proof beyond a reasonable doubt as to
  every essential element of the crime.Â  Sandstrom v. Montana, 442 U.S. 510 (1979).Â  
 
The
  relevant inquiry for the Court in this matter is whether there is a reasonable
  likelihood that the jury applied the challenged instruction in a way that
  violates the Constitution.Â  Estelle v. McGuire, 502 U.S. 62, 72 (1991); Todd v. State, 355 S.C. 396, 403, 585 S.E.2d 305, 309 (2003).Â  In order
  to make this determination, the challenged instruction must be examined in the
  context of the trial courtâ€™s entire charge to the jury and not in isolation.Â Â  Francis
    v. Franklin, 471 U.S. 307, 315 (1985); Todd, 355 S.C. at 402,
  585 S.E.2d at 308.Â  A jury instruction violates due process if it is
  reasonably likely that the jury understood the charge to create a mandatory
  presumption requiring it to infer an element of the offense if the State proved
  certain predicate facts, thereby relieving the Stateâ€™s burden of proof on an
  element of the offense.Â  Francis, 471 U.S. at 314; Sandstrom,
  442 U.S. at 521.Â  The ultimate question for the Court to determine is â€œwhether
  the ailing instruction . . . so infected the entire trial that the resulting
  conviction violates due process.â€Â  Middleton v. McNeil, 541 U.S. 433, 437 (2004) (quoting Estelle, 502 U.S. at 72).Â  Â Â Â Â 
We
  find that the trial courtâ€™s supplemental instruction on felony murder
  unquestionably shifted the burden of proof for the malice element of murder
  from the State to Petitioner.[3]Â 
  Viewed in its entirety, the supplemental jury charge contained no permissive
  language indicating that the jury may infer malice from Petitionerâ€™s
  participation in the armed robbery.Â  Instead, the charge simply provided that if
  the jury first determined that a killing occurred in the course of the armed
  robbery, it must find Petitioner guilty of murder.Â  In this way, the
  charge created a mandatory presumption of the malice element in the crime of
  murder instead of permitting the jury to find malice upon the Stateâ€™s proof of
  the element beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Both this Court and the United States
  Supreme Court have consistently held that such mandatory presumptions of malice
  violate a defendantâ€™s due process.Â  See Yates v. Aiken, 484 U.S. 211 (1988); Francis, 471 U.S. 307; Sandstrom, 442 U.S. 510; Arnold v.
    State/Plath v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 420 S.E.2d 834 (1992) [hereinafter Arnold
      & Plath].
Even
  viewing the supplemental charge in conjunction with the proper instruction on
  felony murder in the trial courtâ€™s initial charge does not rectify this patent
  constitutional error.[4]Â 
  â€œLanguage that merely contradicts and does not explain a constitutionally
  infirm instruction will not suffice to absolve the infirmity.â€ Francis,
  471 U.S. at 322.Â  In fact, these contradictory instructions likely only
  exacerbated the error by confusing the jury as to its fact-finding duties with
  respect to Petitionerâ€™s murder charge.Â  See also State v. Rothell, 301
  S.C. 168, 169-70, 391 S.E.2d 228, 229 (1990) (â€œIt is error to give instructions
  which may confuse or mislead the jury.â€).Â   
The
  fact that the burden-shifting charge occurred in a supplemental instruction is
  also relevant.Â  See Bollenbach v. United States, 326 U.S. 607, 612 (1946) (noting the prominence of presumption language when it arises in a
  supplemental instruction).Â  That the trial court prefaced the supplemental
  charge with the admonition that it was â€œnot to be given any other weight or
  highlighted in any wayâ€ does not alter the fact that the improper charge on
  felony murder was the last thing the jurors heard before beginning
  deliberations and that its brevity was likely received by the jurors with
  â€œheightened alertness rather than the normal attentiveness which may well flag
  from time to time during the lengthy initial charge.â€Â  Arroyo v. Jones, 685 F.2d 35 (2d. Cir. 1982) (finding
  constitutional error in presumption language in a supplemental charge on the
  element of intent because of its special prominence and the series of questions
  from the jury preceding the supplemental charge).Â   
For
  these reasons, there is a reasonable likelihood that the jury understood the
  supplemental charge to create a mandatory presumption that required it to find
  malice if the State proved Petitionerâ€™s involvement in the armed robbery.Â 
  Accordingly, we hold that the juryâ€™s application of the instruction violated Petitionerâ€™s
  due process rights and therefore, that counsel was deficient in failing to
  object to the charge.
The
  analysis in this case, however, does not end here.Â  Certain constitutional errors
  may be harmless in terms of their effect on the fact-finding process at trial.Â  Sullivan vs. Louisiana, 508 U.S. 275, 279 (1993) (quoting Delaware v.
    Van Arsdall, 475 U.S. 673, 681 (1986)).Â  For this reason, an
  unconstitutional jury instruction will not require reversal of the conviction
  if the Court determines â€œbeyond a reasonable doubt that the error complained of
  did not contribute to the verdict obtained.â€Â  Arnold & Plath, 309
  S.C. at 165, 420 S.E.2d at 838 (quoting Chapman v. California, 386 U.S. 18
  (1967)).Â   
Harmless
  error review looks to the basis on which the jury actually rested its verdict.Â  Sullivan, 508 U.S. at 279.Â  From this perspective, in order to conclude
  that the error did not contribute to the verdict, the Court must â€œfind that
  error unimportant in relation to everything else the jury considered on the
  issue in question, as revealed in the record.â€Â  Yates v. Evatt, 500 U.S. 391, 403 (1991).Â  With respect to an unconstitutional presumption in a jury
  instruction, this means the Court must make a judgment about the significance
  of the presumption to the jury, measured against the other evidence considered
  by the jury independently of the presumption.Â  Id. at 403-04.Â  A
  judgment in this regard entails two steps:Â  (1) the Court must ask what
  evidence the jury actually considered in reaching its verdict, and (2) the
  Court must weigh the probative force of the evidence as against the probative
  force of the presumption standing alone. Â Id. at 404.Â   
One
  of the earliest cases in which this Court applied the Yates two-step
  harmless error analysis arose under circumstances similar to the present case. Arnold
    & Plath involved the murder of a hitchhiker by four individuals acting
  in concert.Â  309 S.C. 157, 420 S.E.2d 834.Â  In a joint trial, co-defendants
  Arnold and Plath were each convicted of murder and sentenced to death for their
  involvement in the crime.Â  The defendants filed PCR petitions challenging the
  trial courtâ€™s judgment on the grounds that the charge to the jury
  unconstitutionally shifted the burden of proof for malice.Â  Id.Â  In a
  consolidated appeal from the PCR courtâ€™s denial of relief to Arnold and Plath,
  this Court found that although the trial courtâ€™s charge unconstitutionally
  shifted the burden of proof for malice, the error was harmless beyond a
  reasonable doubt.Â  In its analysis, the Court considered testimony by the
  forensic pathologist describing the extent of the victimâ€™s physical injuries,
  as well as credible testimony by defendant Plath and the two other accomplices
  to the crime detailing the brutality of the victimâ€™s murder.Â  Id. at
  167-170, 420 S.E.2d at 840-41.Â  Based on this extensive testimony, the Court
  held that the probative force of the direct evidence was such that beyond a
  reasonable doubt, the jury could not have rested its verdict solely on the
  presumption of malice.Â  Id. at 171-72, 420 S.E.2d at 841-42.Â 
  Accordingly, this Court affirmed the PCR courtâ€™s denial of relief.Â  See also
    Yates, 500 U.S. at 406 n.10 (explaining that in some cases, the predicate
  facts to be relied on under the presumption may be â€œso closely related to the
  ultimate fact to be presumed that no rational jury could find those facts
  without also finding the ultimate factâ€ (quoting Carella v. California,
  491 U.S. 263, 271 (1989) (Scalia, J., concurring))).Â  Â Â 
In
  applying this two-step analysis to the instant case, we find the evidentiary
  circumstances to be markedly different from those in Arnold & Plath.Â 
  Â Viewing the primary direct evidence against Petitioner at trial and weighing
  the probative force of this evidence against the probative force of the
  presumption standing alone, we find that the direct evidence suggests the jury
  assigned considerable significance to the unconstitutional presumption of
  malice in the trial courtâ€™s supplemental instruction.Â   
At
  Petitionerâ€™s trial, the Stateâ€™s primary direct evidence consisted of three
  statements to police in which Petitioner gave certain information about the
  crime, along with testimony by two of Petitionerâ€™s co-defendants in the
  conspiracy describing Petitionerâ€™s involvement.Â  Additionally, the State
  produced two friends of Petitioner (not involved in the crime) who testified as
  to details allegedly corroborating Petitionerâ€™s involvement in the murder.Â 
  Petitioner himself did not testify at trial and did not produce any witnesses
  or other evidence on his behalf.Â   
We
  find little direct probative evidence of malice in Petitionerâ€™s first two
  statements given to police, which merely provided information about the crime
  and Petitionerâ€™s acknowledgement that he was present at the crime scene.Â  Only
  the final statement - which was unsigned by Petitioner and merely consisted of
  notes by the SLED agent assigned to the case - explained Petitionerâ€™s role as a
  lookout who was to â€œcome out shootingâ€ if police arrived on the scene while the
  crime was taking place.Â  We also find that the credibility of Petitionerâ€™s
  co-defendants who testified that Petitioner was instrumental in planning the
  robbery and murder is questionable at best.Â  Petitioner voluntarily implicated
  both co-defendants prior to Petitioner himself being investigated for the
  crime, and co-defendant Melick Russell even admitted wanting retaliation for
  Petitionerâ€™s turning him in to police.Â  Co-defendant Mimi Allison Hodgesâ€™s
  testimony that she had received a lighter sentence for her role in the crime in
  exchange for her testimony against Petitioner and the other conspirators has
  similar implications on her credibility, in our view.Â   
The
  probative value of Petitionerâ€™s friendsâ€™ testimony with respect to malice is
  also minimal.Â  One friend testified that Petitioner bragged about a murder, but
  also stated that he did not believe Petitionerâ€™s story because â€œwhere Iâ€™m from,
  you kill somebody, you donâ€™t walk around and talk about it.â€Â  Another friend
  who testified Petitioner sold him a gun allegedly taken from the victim during
  the robbery could not produce the gun for comparison purposes.Â  Ultimately, the
  only undisputed relevant facts to be gleaned from the evidence on the record
  are that Petitioner was near the scene of the crime at the time it occurred,
  but was neither the gunman, nor in the getaway car.Â Â Â Â Â   
Even
  though the State points out that the trial court thoroughly instructed the jury
  on its role in evaluating the credibility of witnesses and determining the
  voluntariness of Petitionerâ€™s statements, we find that the evidence considered
  by the jury does not show beyond a reasonable doubt that the juryâ€™s guilty
  murder verdict is not attributable to the unconstitutional presumption of
  malice.Â  In our opinion, there is no overwhelming evidence tending to establish
  Petitionerâ€™s guilt of murder.Â  More specifically, we find that the probative
  force of the undisputed facts along with all other evidence purporting to
  establish Petitionerâ€™s central role in the conspiracy do not rise to the level
  of â€œmaliceâ€ such that we may conclude that the mandatory presumption did not
  play a significant role in the juryâ€™s guilty verdict.Â  Therefore, we hold that
  the unconstitutional presumption of malice articulated in the supplemental jury
  instruction on felony murder did not constitute harmless error beyond a
  reasonable doubt.Â   
Because
  the unconstitutional jury instruction did not constitute harmless error in
  Petitionerâ€™s murder conviction, we find that there is a reasonable probability
  that, but for counselâ€™s failure to object to the unconstitutional jury
  instruction, the outcome of the trial would have been different.Â  See Arnold
    & Plath, 309 S.C. at 165, 420 S.E.2d at 838 (noting that the
  requirement that a constitutional error be harmless beyond a reasonable doubt
  â€œembodies a standard requiring reversal â€˜if there is a reasonable possibility
  that the evidence complained of might have contributed to the convictionâ€™â€ (quoting Yates, 500 U.S. at 403)).Â  Accordingly, we hold that trial counsel was
  ineffective in failing to object to the supplemental charge, and therefore,
  that the PCR court erred in denying Petitionerâ€™s application for relief.Â  
 
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we
  reverse the PCR courtâ€™s decision dismissing Petitionerâ€™s application and grant
  relief as to Petitionerâ€™s murder conviction.
MOORE, WALLER,
  PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.



[1] Appellate counsel briefly outlined the issue in the
  instant case in the Anders brief, but did not raise the issue on direct
  appeal because it had not been preserved for review.Â   
[2] Similar protections are provided in our state constitution.Â  See S.C.
  Const. art. I, Â§ 3.Â   
[3] See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-10 (2003) (â€œâ€˜Murderâ€™ is the killing of
  any person with malice aforethought, either express or implied.â€) (italics in
  original).
[4] The trial courtâ€™s instruction on felony murder in its initial charge to the
  jury is similar to that characterized as a â€œproper charge on implied maliceâ€ by
  this Court.Â  See State v. Norris, 285 S.C. 86, 92, 328 S.E.2d 339, 343
  (1985) (overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C.
  45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991)).Â Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				
				In the Matter of David Harold Hanna, Sr., Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26437
January 15, 2008 - Filed February 11, 2008 
DISBARRED


	
		
			
				Lesley M.
  Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Deputy Disciplinary
  Counsel, both of Columbia, forÂ  Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
				David
  Harold Hanna, Sr., of Spartanburg, pro se.Â  
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule
  413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to any
  sanction in Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  Respondent requests that, if the
  Court imposes a period of suspension or disbarment, that the suspension or
  disbarment be made retroactive to the date of his interim suspension, January
  18, 2007.Â  In the Matter of Hanna, 371 S.C. 510, 640 S.E.2d 871 (2007).Â 
  In addition, respondent agrees to pay the costs incurred by ODC and the
  Commission on Lawyer Conduct in investigating this matter.Â  We accept the
  agreement and disbar respondent from the practice of law in this state,
  retroactive to the date of his interim suspension. Â The facts, as set forth in
  the agreement, are as follows.Â   
FACTS
Respondent
  admits the material portions of the factual allegations set out in the Formal
  Charges.Â  The Formal Charges charge respondent with nine instances of misconduct.
 

Matter I
Complainant
  A was the heir of the late Mr. and Mrs. Doe.Â  Respondent had prepared a will
  for Mr. Doe.Â  Mr. Doe passed away.Â  Respondent prepared a will for Mrs. Doe.Â 
  Mrs. Doe passed away shortly after Mr. Doe and before his estate was closed.Â  The
  will prepared for Mrs. Doe included a devise of real property to respondent.Â 
 
Prior her
  death, respondent purchased a truck from Mrs. Doe that had belonged to Mr.
  Doe.Â  Respondent entered into this business transaction with his client without
  complying with the consultation and consent requirements of the Rules of
  Professional Conduct.Â  Respondent did not timely respond to the initial inquiry
  and several requests for additional information from ODC regarding this matter.

Matter II
Complainant
  B paid respondent $2,500.00 to assist him in a custody dispute.Â  Respondent did
  not hold the retainer in trust until it was earned.Â  There were delays and
  continuances in the matter.Â  Respondent did not adequately communicate with
  Complainant B regarding the scheduling of the hearing.Â  Respondent did not
  respond to the initial inquiry or the Treacy[1] letter from ODC.Â   

Matter III
In 1999,
  certain real property was deeded to Complainants Mr. and Mrs. Jones in a
  closing conducted by a contract attorney for a closing services company called
  Magnolia Title.Â  In 2003, Mr. and Mrs. Jones attempted to sell the property.Â 
  At that time, they learned that the property description in the 1999 deed was
  incorrect.Â  By that time, the grantor had died.
Respondent
  was a contract attorney for Magnolia Title.[2]Â 
  He also served as legal counsel for Magnolia Title.Â  Respondent prepared a
  corrective deed and contacted the heir to the grantor.Â  The heir indicated she
  was not willing to sign a corrective deed until she spoke with Mr. and Mrs.
  Jones.Â  She requested respondent arrange a meeting.Â  She did not hear anything
  further from respondent.Â   
A
  corrective deed was filed.Â  The signature of the grantorâ€™s heir was forged and
  falsely witnessed and notarized.Â  Respondent recorded the deed.Â   
When the
  forgery was discovered by Mr. and Mrs. Jones, respondent sent a proposed
  agreement in which they would agree to â€œuse all efforts possible to correct a
  title problemâ€ for the property, that â€œthere was a clerical error in the past
  deed,â€ and that they would â€œuse their best efforts in assisting Magnolia Title
  Agency Incorporated in any and all methods necessary to complete this actionâ€¦includingâ€¦
assisting in any court
  action.â€Â  Mr. and Mrs. Jones did not sign this agreement.Â  Respondent did not
  disclose the conflict of interest created by his representation of his clientsâ€™
  interests and the interests of Magnolia Title either prior to or subsequent to
  sending the proposed agreement.Â   
Mr. and
  Mrs. Jones specifically instructed respondent not to sue the grantorâ€™s heir on
  their behalf.Â  Respondent filed a quiet title action against the grantorâ€™s heir
  naming Magnolia Title and Mr. and Mrs. Jones as plaintiffs.Â   
Respondent
  did not timely respond to ODCâ€™s written inquires in this matter.

Matter IV
In July
  2004, Complainant C paid respondent $1,750.00 to represent her in a custody
  matter involving her grandchildren.Â  ODC investigated the allegations of
  neglect, incompetence, and lack of adequate communication and concluded there
  was not clear and convincing evidence to support Complainant Câ€™s allegations.Â  Respondent
  failed to submit a timely response to the initial inquiry from ODC.Â   

Matter V
Complainant
  D was represented by respondentâ€™s partner in a civil case.Â  Complainant D
  obtained a favorable judgment, but the defendant was in bankruptcy.Â  Respondent
  agreed to assist with collection of the judgment since he handled bankruptcy
  cases for the firm.Â   
Subsequently,
  respondent left the partnership and took the file with him.Â  He collected a
  number of payments from the bankruptcy trustee and passed them onto Complainant
  D.Â  Respondent did not withhold any fees or costs from those payments.Â   
In May
  2005, respondent received a check for $5,000.00 from the proceeds of the sale
  of the defendantâ€™s real property.Â  Respondent placed this money in his trust
  account.Â  He told Complainant D that he needed to review the bankruptcy
  payments and check with his former firm about the fee arrangements and costs
  incurred in the civil case.Â  By August 2005, Complainant D had not heard
  anything from respondent so she contacted his former firm.Â   
After
  receiving notice of this grievance, respondent contacted his former firm to
  attempt to get the matter resolved.Â  When their communications broke down,
  respondentâ€™s attorney advised him to hold the funds in his trust account.Â  On
  August 27, 2006, respondent sent Complainant D a trust account check for the
  full $5,000.00.  
ODC
  requested copies of respondentâ€™s bank statements to verify that the funds had
  remained in trust until disbursed.Â  Respondent did not comply with this
  request.Â Â Â Â   

Matter VI
Respondent
  established a business relationship with Magnolia Title, a closing services
  company owned by a non-lawyer.Â  The relationship included respondentâ€™s
  representation of Magnolia Titleâ€™s clients in real estate closings and the
  representation of Magnolia Title in claims and litigation arising from
  closings.Â  Respondent was one of the several contract attorneys who conducted
  closings for Magnolia Title.
The
  common practice for non-lawyer staff of Magnolia Title included the preparation
  of title abstracts and closing documents for respondentâ€™s review.Â  The closing
  attorney (respondent or another lawyer) would then conduct the closing and
  return the documents and money to Magnolia Title.Â  Disbursements of settlement
  proceeds were made at the closings prior to the deposit of funds.Â  The
  non-lawyer staff would then conduct post-closing activities such as recording
  the documents and obtaining title insurance.Â   
Respondent
  allowed Magnolia Title to open an IOLTA account on which he shared signatory
  authority with a non-lawyer paralegal employed by Magnolia Title.Â  Magnolia
  Title used that trust account for all of its closings, regardless of whether
  respondent handled the closing.Â  Respondent ultimately severed his ties with
  Magnolia Title, but he did not close the trust account.
Magnolia
  Title used an out-of-state bookkeeping service for reconciliation and
  management of the trust account.Â  Respondent did not have access to the
  Magnolia Title trust account records when ODC requested them.Â  Respondent did
  not instruct the non-lawyer staff of Magnolia Title or the out-of-state
  bookkeeping company regarding the requirements of Rule 417, SCACR.Â   
Complainant
  E rented real property to Mr. Smith.Â  Mr. Smith wanted to purchase the
  property.Â  Complainant E agreed to finance the purchase with a $3,000.00 down
  payment.Â  Complainant E asked respondent to handle the closing for Mr. Smith.Â 
  Mr. Smith gave Complainant E a personal check for the down payment plus closing
  costs. Â Complainant E negotiated the personal check for a cashierâ€™s check,
  delivered it to Magnolia Title, and scheduled the closing.Â   
Respondent
  conducted the closing and delivered the documents to Magnolia Title to record.Â 
  The deed and mortgage were not recorded.Â  When Complainant E contacted
  respondent after the closing, respondent assured him that the documents had
  been recorded.Â   
Complainant
  E discovered that the deed and mortgage had not been recorded when he received
  a tax notice on the property six months later.Â  By that time, Mr. Smith had
  defaulted on some of his mortgage payments.Â  Respondent advised Complainant E
  not to file the deed and mortgage at that time in order to avoid a foreclosure.Â 
 
ODC made
  repeated inquiries to respondent regarding an accounting of funds paid from Mr.
  Smithâ€™s check to Magnolia Title for recording fees, deed stamps, title
  insurance premiums, etc., that should have been refunded.Â  Respondent did not
  respond.Â  
 

Matter VII
Complainant
  F retained respondent to represent her in connection with injuries sustained in
  an automobile accident on March 2, 2001.Â  When respondent left his law firm to
  start a solo practice, he took Complainant Fâ€™s file with him.  
Complainant
  F incurred $55,000.00 in medical bills.Â  Respondent submitted a demand in
  January 2004.Â  The claim was not settled.Â   
On March
  3, 2004, the day after the statute of limitations expired, respondent filed
  suit.Â  The pleadings had been back-dated to March 1, 2004.Â  Respondent was
  unable to locate the defendant for service. He did not attempt service by
  publication.Â  The lawsuit was dismissed.Â   
Respondent
  did not have malpractice insurance.Â  He attempted to settle with Complainant F
  for $8,000.00.Â  In his communications with Complainant F regarding this
  proposal, respondent did not comply with the disclosure and consultation
  requirements of the Rules of Professional Conduct.Â Â Â   

Matter VIII
Complainant
  G hired respondent for three legal matters.Â  Respondent failed to adequately
  communicate with Complainant G regarding those matters.  
Respondent
  failed to timely respond to the Notice of Full Investigation in this matter.Â 
  Respondent failed to respond to ODCâ€™s request for additional information.


Matter IX
Complainant
  H hired respondent to represent him in a bankruptcy matter.Â  A creditorsâ€™
  meeting was held on May 30, 2006.Â  At that meeting, the trustee raised concerns
  about Complainant Hâ€™s transfer of real estate to his daughter prior to filing
  bankruptcy.  
Respondent
  asked Complainant H to gather documents related to the conveyance.Â  Complainant
  H complied with this request and met with respondentâ€™s assistant in his absence
  on June 9, 2006.Â  The assistant drafted a letter of explanation to the trustee
  and enclosed the documents.Â  She left the draft and documents for respondentâ€™s
  review.Â   
Complainant
  H tried repeatedly to contact respondent, but he did not respond.Â  As of July
  21, 2006, the date Complainant H submitted his grievance, he had not heard from
  respondent.
In his
  response to ODC, respondent stated he did review the draft letter prepared by
  his assistant but did not send it because he wanted to include a copy of the
  appraisal which he claimed Complainant H had not yet provided.Â  Respondent
  submitted copies of a number of letters that he claimed he sent to Complainant
  H asking for a copy of the appraisal.Â  Complainant H never received these
  letters.Â   
Ultimately,
  respondent submitted the letter to the trustee on August 21, 2006, after
  receiving notice of the grievance.Â  The only change respondent made to the
  draft initially prepared by his assistant was to add a paragraph that said the
  delay was due to Complainant Hâ€™s failure to provide documentation to respondent
  and that Complainant H had become forgetful.Â   
While
  Complaint Hâ€™s matter was pending before the bankruptcy court, the Honorable
  John E. Waites, United States Bankruptcy Judge, submitted a copy of the order
  of the bankruptcy court in In the Matter of Farnsworth indefinitely
  suspending respondent from practicing before the bankruptcy court in this state
  to ODC.Â  This indefinite suspension followed various sanctions against
  respondent in fourteen prior matters from 2003 to 2006.Â  These prior sanctions
  were imposed for a variety of problems, including failing to obtain debtorsâ€™
  signatures on schedules and amended plans, failing to disclose previous
  filings, deficient representation, violating local rules, filing improper
  motions, and failing to timely remit filing fees.  

LAW
Respondent admits that, by his
  misconduct, he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of
  Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide
  competent representation to client); Rule 1.2 (lawyer shall abide by clientâ€™s
  decisions concerning objectives of representations); Rule 1.3 (lawyer 
shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness
    in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep client reasonably informed about
      the status of a matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for
      information); Rule 1.7(a) (lawyer shall not represent client if
  representation will be directly adverse to another client unless lawyer
  reasonably believes representation will not adversely affect relationship with
  the other client and each client consents after consultation); Rule 1.7(b) (lawyer
  shall not represent client if the representation of that client may be
  materially limited by the lawyerâ€™s responsibilities to a third person unless lawyer
  reasonably believes the representation will not be adversely affected and the
  client consents after consultation); Rule 1.8(a) (lawyer shall not enter
  into business transaction with a client unless terms are fair and client
  consents in writing); Rule 1.8(c) (lawyer shall not prepare an instrument
  giving lawyer substantial gift from a client); Rule 1.8(h) (lawyer shall not
  settle a claim for liability with unrepresented client or former client unless
  that person is advised in writing of desirability of seeking and reasonable
  opportunity to seek independent legal counsel); Rule 1.9 (lawyer who has formerly
  represented client in matter shall not thereafter represent another person in
  same or substantially related matter in which that personâ€™s interests are
  materially adverse to the interest of the former client unless the former
  client gives informed consent in writing); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall promptly
  deliver funds to which client is entitled; lawyer shall deposit unearned legal
  fees into trust account and withdraw funds only when earned); Rule 3.3 (lawyer
  shall not knowingly make false statement of fact to tribunal); Rule 5.3 (lawyer
  having direct supervisory authority over non-lawyer shall make reasonable
  efforts to ensure that personâ€™s conduct is compatible with professional
  obligations of lawyer and shall be responsible for non-lawyerâ€™s conduct if
  conduct would be a violation of Rules of Professional Conduct if engaged in by
  lawyer); Rule 8.1(b) (lawyer shall not knowingly fail to respond to lawful demand
  for information from disciplinary authority); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional
  misconduct for a lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(d)
  (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct involving
  dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (it is
  professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial
  to the administration of justice).[3]Â  
 
Respondent further admits his
  misconduct is grounds for discipline under Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR,
  specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to
  violate Rules of Professional Conduct), Rule 7(a)(2) (it shall be ground for
  discipline for lawyer to engage in conduct violating applicable rules of professional
  conduct in another jurisdiction), Rule 7(a)(3) (it shall be ground for
  discipline for lawyer to knowingly fail to respond to a lawful demand from
  disciplinary authority), Rule 7(a)(5) ( it shall be ground for discipline for
  lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute administration of justice, bring
  courts or legal profession into disrepute, or conduct demonstrating an
  unfitness to practice law), and Rule 7(a)(7) (it shall be ground for discipline
  for lawyer to willfully violate a court order). Â In addition, respondent admits
  his misconduct violated Rule 417, SCACR.Â  
   

CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline
  by Consent and disbar respondent.Â  The disbarment shall be retroactive to the
  date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  Within thirty (30) days of the date
  of this opinion, respondent shall pay the costs incurred by ODC and the
  Commission on Lawyer Conduct in the investigation of these matters.Â  Within
  fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit
  with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413,
  SCACR, and shall also surrender his Certificate of Admission to the Practice of
  Law to the Clerk of Court.Â   
In addition, should it be determined
  that any restitution remains outstanding, ODC and respondent shall file a
  restitution plan with the Court within thirty (30) days of the date of this
  opinion.Â  In the plan, respondent shall agree to pay restitution to all
  clients, banks, and other persons and entities who have incurred losses as a
  result of his misconduct in connection with this matter.Â  Moreover, in the
  restitution plan, respondent shall agree to reimburse the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for
  Client Protection for any claims paid as a result of his misconduct in
  connection with this matter.Â   
DISBARRED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1] See In the Matter of Treacy, 277 S.C. 514, 290 S.E.2d 240 (1982).Â  
 
[2] Respondent was not the contract attorney who
  conducted the 1999 closing for Mr. and Mrs. Jones.Â   
[3] The Rules
  of Professional Conduct cited in this opinion are those which were in effect at
  the time of respondentâ€™s misconduct.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				
				Larry Lorenzen, Respondent,
				
				v.
				
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Aiken County
Â Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26438
Submitted December 6, 2007 - Filed
  February 11, 2008Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Lance S.
  Boozer, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Appellate
  Defender Robert M. Pachak, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense,
  Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  In this post-conviction
  relief (PCR) case, the Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for certiorari to
  review the PCR judgeâ€™s decision granting relief with respect to Larry Lorenzenâ€™s
  convictions for first-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor and second-degree
  criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
At
  trial, the following facts were established regarding the charges.Â  The victim,
  who was fourteen years old at the time of trial, testified Lorenzen was a
  family friend who regularly spent time with her mother and often visited her
  father at his separate residence.Â  The victim claimed that when she was left
  alone with Lorenzen:Â  (1) he began touching her â€œprivatesâ€ when she was nine
  years old; (2) he digitally penetrated her when she was ten years old; and (3) he
  attempted to have sexual intercourse with her when she was eleven years old. Â A
  few weeks after the sexual intercourse incident, the victim told her mother, a school
  teacher, and the school psychologist about the abuse.Â   
Subsequently,
  school officials reported the victimâ€™s allegations of sexual abuse to the Aiken
  County Sheriffâ€™s Department.Â  After the initial interview, the victim was
  immediately examined by an emergency room doctor.Â  Two weeks later, a physician
  with the Lexington County Childrenâ€™s Center examined the victim to determine
  whether she had been subjected to chronic sexual abuse.Â  Neither examination
  revealed physical evidence of sexual assault.Â  However, both physicians
  testified that the absence of such evidence did not necessarily negate the
  victimâ€™s allegations of sexual abuse.  
After
  the abuse had been revealed, the victim was involved in several violent
  incidents with family members and others which resulted in her being committed
  to the Department of Juvenile Justice (DJJ).
Dr.
  Kay Jordan, a counselor specializing in child sexual abuse, was qualified as an
  expert witness for the State.Â  Dr. Jordan testified that she had eighteen
  counseling sessions with the victim between July 2000 and December 2000.Â  According
  to Dr. Jordan, the victim exhibited symptoms of sexual abuse in that she had nightmares,
  flashbacks, and became violent.Â  Based on her sessions, Dr. Jordan diagnosed the victim with post-traumatic stress disorder.Â  Dr. Jordan explained that her diagnosis was also based on the victimâ€™s history of psychiatric
  treatment for these symptoms which began when the victim was nine or ten years
  old.  
Lorenzen
  declined to testify in his defense and did not offer any witnesses.Â  The jury
  convicted Lorenzen of first-degree CSC with a minor, second-degree CSC with a
  minor, and lewd act upon a child.Â  The trial judge, however, granted defense
  counselâ€™s motion for a new trial on the lewd act upon a child charge because
  the State failed to offer evidence that Lorenzen was over the age of fourteen
  years when the act occurred.Â  On the two remaining charges, the judge sentenced
  Lorenzen to life in prison without the possibility of parole pursuant to
  section 17-25-45 of the South Carolina Code.[1]
After
  the Court of Appeals affirmed his convictions and sentence, Lorenzen filed an
  application for post-conviction relief. Â State v. Larry Lorenzen, Op.
  No. 2003-UP-436 (S.C. Ct. App. filed June 25, 2003). Â 
At
  the PCR hearing, Lorenzen testified that he believed his trial counsel should
  have retained an expert witness to:Â  (1) examine him in order to prove that he
  was not a pedophile; (2) discuss the lack of physical evidence of sexual abuse;
  (3) delve into the psychological issues of the victim; and (4) challenge Dr. Jordanâ€™s testimony.Â  Lorenzen also stated that it would have been helpful for the jury to
  have heard that the victimâ€™s father was on the sexual offender registry.Â 
  Lorenzen further asserted that it might have made a difference if he had
  testified at trial.Â  However, he admitted the â€œcase was stacked againstâ€ him at
  the point he would have testified.Â  He ultimately asserted that counselâ€™s
  â€œperformance prejudiced [him] such that it rendered the proceeding
  fundamentally unfair.â€  
During
  her testimony, trial counsel admitted that Lorenzenâ€™s case was only her third
  jury trial and her first trial involving a sex crime.Â  She testified she had
  become more experienced with this type of case since Lorenzenâ€™s trial.Â 
  Specifically, she had learned that it is helpful to have the defendant examined
  by a forensic psychologist in order to assess the personâ€™s propensity for
  engaging in the alleged sexually-deviant behavior.Â  Additionally, she believed
  it would have been beneficial for an independent doctor to review the victimâ€™s medical
  records.Â  In terms of the victimâ€™s records, counsel stated she had the records
  from the victimâ€™s sessions with the sexual abuse counselor as well as the records
  from the psychological facilities that treated the victim.Â  Counsel, however,
  stated the victimâ€™s police interview was not videotaped, which she now knew was
  part of the suggested protocol in child victim cases. Â She also acknowledged
  that expert witnesses could have been called to counter Dr. Jordanâ€™s testimony.Â  Counsel further testified she was not aware at the time of trial that
  the victimâ€™s father was on the sexual offender registry.Â  Had she known this
  fact, counsel stated she would have cross-examined the Stateâ€™s expert witness
  regarding the possibility that the victim was abused by her father. Â Finally,
  counsel informed the court that the public defenderâ€™s office was short staffed
  at the time of trial.Â  As a result, she did not have a more experienced public
  defender assisting her during the trial.  
The
  PCR judge granted Lorenzenâ€™s application for relief.Â  The judge found that
  â€œtrial counsel did not adequately prepare for the trial and the defense of
  [the] charges.â€Â  In reaching this decision, the judge noted that counsel was
  not only â€œlacking in experience,â€ but â€œshe was also lacking in assistance at
  the office.â€Â  In terms of the specifics of trial counselâ€™s performance, the
  judge addressed several areas where he felt counsel was deficient.Â   
Specifically,
  the judge found counsel failed to:Â  (1) retain or even consult with an expert witness;
  (2) conduct an investigation to determine whether another individual,
  particularly the victimâ€™s father who was listed on the sexual offender
  registry, could have been responsible for sexually abusing the victim; (3) have
  Lorenzen submit to a polygraph examination in order to assist in the defense;
  (4) obtain the minor victimâ€™s records from the sexual abuse counselor, the
  Department of Juvenile Justice, and the Department of Social Services; and (5) meet
  with the minor child prior to trial.Â   
Ultimately,
  the judge concluded that â€œ[a]ll of these shortcomings are problematic.Â  While
  no individual failure alone would be a ground for granting this PCR, the
  cumulative neglect is severe.â€ Â In reaching his decision to grant Lorenzenâ€™s
  petition for relief, the judge relied on this Courtâ€™s opinion in Nance v.
    Frederick, 358 S.C. 480, 596 S.E.2d 62 (2004).[2] Â The judge recognized that Lorenzenâ€™s counsel was not as deficient as counsel
  in Nance.Â  However, he found Lorenzenâ€™s counselâ€™s â€œfailure to properly
  and adequately prepare for the trial and prepare [Lorenzenâ€™s] defense in
  general amounted to a complete denial of counsel and failed to subject the
  prosecutionâ€™s case to a meaningful adversarial testing.â€Â  Based on this
  assessment, the judge granted Lorenzenâ€™s application â€œbecause, essentially,
  trial counsel was ineffective for failing to prepare and present [Lorenzenâ€™s]
  case as required under the Sixth Amendment.â€Â   
This
  Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s
  decision.
DISCUSSION
A
  defendant has the right to the effective assistance of counsel under the Sixth
  Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  United States v. Cronic,
  466 U.S. 648 (1984); Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).Â  â€œThere is a strong presumption that counsel rendered adequate assistance
  and exercised reasonable professional judgment in making all significant
  decisions in the case.â€Â  Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318, 331, 642 S.E.2d
  590, 596 (2007), cert. denied, 128 S. Ct. 370 (2007).
In a
  PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he is
  entitled to relief.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d
  514, 517 (2000).Â  â€œ[P]etitioner must meet the standard established in Strickland
    v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).â€Â  Edmond v. State, 341
  S.C. 340, 346, 534 S.E.2d 682, 685 (2000).Â  In order to establish a claim of
  ineffective assistance of counsel, the PCR applicant must show that: Â (1)
  counselâ€™s performance was deficient; and (2) there is a reasonable probability
  that, but for counselâ€™s errors, the result of the trial would have been
  different.Â  Caprood, 338 S.C. at 109, 525 S.E.2d at 517 (citing Strickland
    v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984)).Â  â€œA reasonable probability is a
  probability sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcome of the trial.â€Â  Ard,
  372 S.C. at 331, 642 S.E.2d at 596. Â â€œFurthermore, when a defendantâ€™s
  conviction is challenged, â€˜the question is whether there is a reasonable
  probability that, absent the errors, the fact finder would have had a reasonable
  doubt respecting guilt.â€™â€ Id. (quoting Strickland v. Washington,
  466 U.S. 668, 695 (1984)).Â   
â€œThis
  Court gives great deference to the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s
  findings of fact and conclusions of law.â€Â  Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C.
  365, 368, 610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005).Â  A PCR courtâ€™s findings will be upheld on
  appeal if there is â€œany evidence of probative value sufficient to support
  them.â€Â  Id.Â  This Court will reverse the PCR courtâ€™s decision when it is
  controlled by an error
  of law.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 651, 594 S.E.2d 462, 465
  (2004).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Generally, an
  applicant must show actual prejudice under Strickland.Â  The United
  States Supreme Court and this Court have recognized that in certain limited
  circumstances â€œâ€˜prejudice is presumedâ€™ because prejudice â€˜is so likely that
  case-by-case inquiry . . . is not worth the cost.â€™â€Â  Nance, 367 S.C. at
  551, 626 S.E.2d at 880 (quoting Strickland, 466 U.S. at 692)); Cronic, 466 U.S. at 658. Â In analyzing these narrow circumstances, this Court
  explained:

	In Cronic,
  the Court identified three distinct situations in which a presumption of
  prejudice is appropriate. First, prejudice is presumed when the defendant is
  completely denied counsel â€œat a critical stage of his trial.â€Â  Cronic,
  466 U.S. at 659, 104 S.Ct. 2039.Â  Second, per-se prejudice occurs if there has
  been a constructive denial of counsel. This happens when a lawyer â€œentirely
  fails to subject the prosecutionâ€™s case to meaningful adversarial testing,â€
  thus making â€œthe adversary process itself presumptively unreliable.â€ Id.Â  Third, the Court identified certain instances â€œwhen although counsel is
  available to assist the accused during trial, the likelihood that any lawyer,
  even a fully competent one, could provide effective assistance is so small that
  a presumption of prejudice is appropriate without inquiry into the actual
  conduct of the trial.â€ Id. (citing Powell v. Alabama, 287 U.S. 45, 53 S.Ct. 55, 77 L.Ed. 158 (1932)). Â A finding of per-se prejudice under any of
  these three prongs is â€œan extremely high showing for a criminal defendant to
  make.â€ Brown v. French, 147 F.3d 307, 313 (4th Cir. 1998).

Nance, 367 S.C. at 552, 626 S.E.2d at 880.Â 
  Although an applicant â€œmust ordinarily show actual prejudice, he may be
  relieved of that burden if counselâ€™s ineffectiveness is so pervasive as to
  render a particularized prejudice inquiry unnecessary.â€Â  Green v. State,
  351 S.C. 184, 196, 569 S.E.2d 318, 324 (2002).Â   
I.
The
  State argues the PCR judge erred in finding that trial counsel was ineffective
  for failing to call expert witnesses during Lorenzenâ€™s trial.Â  For several
  reasons, we agree with the Stateâ€™s assertion.Â   
First,
  Lorenzen failed to present evidence that would show a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s failure to call
  expert witnesses, the result of his trial would have been different.Â  Aside
  from his testimony and his trial counselâ€™s testimony, Lorenzen did not offer
  any other witnesses to testify on his behalf at the PCR hearing.Â  Therefore, it
  is merely speculative that these allegedly favorable expert witnesses would
  have aided in his defense.Â  See Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C. 365, 369,
  610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005) (â€œA PCR applicant cannot show that he was prejudiced
  by counselâ€™s failure to call a favorable witness to testify at trial if that
  witness does not later testify at the PCR hearing or otherwise offer testimony
  within the rules of evidence.â€); see also Porter v. State, 368
  S.C. 378, 386, 629 S.E.2d 353, 358 (2006) (â€œMere speculation of what a witnessâ€™
  testimony may be is insufficient to satisfy the burden of showing prejudice in
  a petition for PCR.â€).  
Secondly,
  counselâ€™s failure to procure expert witnesses did not render her representation
  deficient given she vigorously cross-examined the Stateâ€™s witnesses and
  attacked the accuracy of the evidence.Â  See Frasier v. State, 306
  S.C. 158, 160-61, 410 S.E.2d 572, 573 (1991) (finding trial counsel was not
  deficient in failing to procure an expert witness to challenge DNA evidence
  presented at trial where the record established that counsel vigorously
  cross-examined the Stateâ€™s DNA experts and attacked the accuracy of the
  evidence).Â  At trial, Lorenzenâ€™s counsel attacked the Stateâ€™s evidence through
  cross-examination as well as by positing objections when appropriate.Â Â Â 
  Counsel also vigorously cross-examined Dr. Jordan, the Stateâ€™s expert witness. Significantly,
  Lorenzen admitted at the PCR hearing that counsel had brought out â€œsome good
  pointsâ€ during her cross-examination.Â  Finally, it is noteworthy that counsel
  in preparing her case had the assistance of two public defenders.Â  Neither
  public defender recommended or suggested that counsel retain expert witnesses
  for Lorenzenâ€™s defense.  
Because Lorenzen
  failed to meet his burden that trial counsel was deficient and that the result
  of his trial would have been different but for this alleged deficiency, we hold
  the PCR judge erred in finding Lorenzenâ€™s counselâ€™s failure to call expert
  witnesses was a critical error in the alleged cumulative errors that
  constituted ineffective assistance of counsel.
II.
The
  State contends the PCR judge erred in finding Lorenzenâ€™s trial counsel was
  ineffective for failing to raise the fact that the victimâ€™s father was on the
  sexual offender registry. Â We agree with the Stateâ€™s contention.Â   
Because the PCR
  judge admitted the registry without explanation over the Stateâ€™s objection, it
  is difficult to discern the basis for its admission.Â  In any event, we conclude
  the sexual offender registry would not have been admissible at trial.Â   
â€œOur Supreme Court has imposed strict limitations on the
  admissibility of third-party
  guilt.â€ State v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 81, 538 S.E.2d 257, 265 (Ct.
  App. 2000).Â  â€œEvidence offered by a defendant as to the commission of the crime
  by another person is limited to facts which are inconsistent with the defendantâ€™s
  guilt.â€ Id. Â Recently, after
  Lorenzenâ€™s trial and PCR hearing, our United States Supreme Court clarified the
  above-outlined rule regarding the admission of third-party guilt in Holmes
    v. South Carolina, 547 U.S. 319 (2006).Â  In Holmes, the Supreme
  Court considered the question of â€œwhether a criminal defendantâ€™s federal
  constitutional rights are violated by [a South Carolina] evidence rule under
  which the defendant may not introduce proof of third-party guilt if the
  prosecution has introduced forensic evidence that, if believed, strongly
  supports a guilty verdict.â€Â  Id. at 321.Â  The Supreme Court answered this
  question in the affirmative.Â  The Courtâ€™s holding essentially permits a
  defendant to introduce evidence of third-party guilt regardless of the strength
  of the Stateâ€™s case if the evidence meets the following criteria:

	[E]vidence offered by accused as to the
  commission of the crime by another person must be limited to such facts as are
  inconsistent with his own guilt, and to such facts as raise a reasonable
  inference or presumption as to his own innocence; evidence which can have (no)
  other effect than to cast a bare suspicion upon another, or to raise a
  conjectural inference as to the commission of the crime by another, is not
  admissible . . . . [B]efore such testimony can be received, there must be such
  proof of connection with it, such a train of facts or circumstances, as tends
  clearly to point out such other person as the guilty party. 198 S.C., at 104-105,
  16 S.E.2d, at 534-535 (quoting 16 C.J., Criminal Law Â§ 1085, p. 560 (1918) and
  20 Am.Jur., Evidence Â§ 20 265, p. 254 (1939); footnotes omitted).

Holmes, 547 U.S. at 328 (quoting State v.
  Gregory, 198 S.C. 98, 16 S.E.2d 532 (1941)).
Applying
  the foregoing to the facts of the instant case, we find the sexual offender
  registry listing the victimâ€™s fatherâ€™s name would not have been admissible
  under either a pre- or post-Holmes third-party guilt standard.Â  Significantly,
  the victimâ€™s father was listed on the registry for committing the crime of
  assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct in the first degree which
  would have involved an adult victim whereas Lorenzen was charged with criminal
  sexual conduct with a minor.Â  Lorenzenâ€™s counsel at the PCR hearing
  acknowledged there was nothing on the registry to indicate the victimâ€™s father
  committed a crime against a child.Â  Furthermore, Lorenzenâ€™s allegation that the
  victimâ€™s father may have been the perpetrator was so nebulous that it would
  have had no other effect than to â€œcast a bare suspicion.â€Â  Therefore, we do not
  believe these facts would be inconsistent with Lorenzenâ€™s guilt or raise a
  reasonable inference of his innocence.Â  Accordingly, we find the PCR judge
  erred in using this alleged error as a ground for finding Lorenzenâ€™s counsel
  ineffective.
III.
The
  State avers the PCR judge erred in finding that Lorenzenâ€™s counsel was
  ineffective for failing to have Lorenzen submit to a polygraph examination. Â We
  agree with the State.  
â€œThis Court has
  consistently held the results of polygraph examinations are generally not
  admissible because the reliability of the tests is questionable.â€Â  State v.
    Council, 335 S.C. 1, 23, 515 S.E.2d 508, 519 (1999), cert. denied,
  528 U.S. 1050 (1999).Â  Although this Court in Council declined to
  recognize a per se rule against the admission of polygraph
  evidence, it indicated that the â€œadmissibility of this type of scientific
  evidence should be analyzed under Rules 702 and 403, SCRE and the Jones factors.â€Â  Id. at 24, 515 S.E.2d at 520.
Initially, we note
  the polygraph issue was not presented to the judge by either Lorenzen or his
  counsel.Â  Instead, the judge essentially sua sponte raised the issue.Â  Given
  this procedural posture, it was mere speculation on the part of the PCR judge
  to find the admission of a favorable polygraph examination would have aided in
  Lorenzenâ€™s defense.Â  Significantly, the PCR judge conceded that â€œ[w]hile the
  result of any polygraph examination would obviously only be speculative, the
  fact that one was not performed is problematic.â€Â  Without the results of a
  polygraph examination or any other evidence concerning its admission, it is
  difficult to definitively assess whether it would have been admissible at
  trial.Â  Because this type of evidence is rarely admitted, we do not believe the
  facts would support its admission.Â  Therefore, we find Lorenzen did not meet
  his burden to establish a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel based on
  this ground.
IV.
The
  State argues the PCR judge erred in finding Lorenzenâ€™s counsel was ineffective
  for failing to obtain the victimâ€™s records from Dr. Jordan, the Department of
  Juvenile Justice, and the Department of Social Services. Â We agree with the
  State.
At the PCR hearing,
  Lorenzenâ€™s trial counsel specifically testified:

	I had
  extensive records in this case provided to me by the State, not only from [Dr.]
  Jordanâ€™s visit with [the victim] but also from priorâ€”I had the records of all
  of the physical exams that had been done as well as extensive records from [the
  victimâ€™s] prior commitments to certain psychological facilities and I believe
  that I had her D.J.J. records as well.

Additionally, counsel
  informed the PCR judge that she had the assistance of two other public
  defenders helping her prepare the case by extensively reviewing all of these
  records.Â  Because there is no evidence in the record to support this finding, we
  hold the PCR judge clearly erred in relying in part on this ground to grant
  Lorenzenâ€™s application for relief. Â Â See Scott v. State, 334 S.C.
  248, 252, 513 S.E.2d 100, 102 (1999) (stating â€œan appellate court will not affirm the decision when it is
  not supported by any probative evidenceâ€); see also Dempsey v. State,
  363 S.C. 365, 368, 610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005) (A PCR courtâ€™s findings will be
  upheld on appeal if there is â€œany evidence of probative value sufficient to
  support them.â€).Â  Furthermore, Lorenzen failed to show that counselâ€™s review of
  additional records would have been beneficial to his defense.Â  Lorenzenâ€™s claim
  that the records would have changed the result of his trial was speculative at
  best given he did not present evidence that other records existed or that the
  records reviewed by counsel included exculpatory evidence.
V.
The
  State asserts the PCR judge erred in finding Lorenzenâ€™s counsel was ineffective
  for failing to interview the victim prior to trial.Â  We agree with the Stateâ€™s
  assertion.
Initially,
  we note that Lorenzen failed to specifically raise this issue or present any
  evidence at the hearing that interviewing the victim would have led to a
  different result at trial.Â  Thus, we believe that Lorenzenâ€™s mere speculation
  was insufficient to meet his burden to establish that counsel was ineffective.Â  See Moorehead v. State, 329 S.C. 329, 334, 496 S.E.2d 415, 417 (1998)
  (â€œFailure to conduct an independent investigation does not constitute
  ineffective assistance of counsel when the allegation is supported only by mere
  speculation as to the result.â€).Â  Finally, we note that counsel cross-examined
  the victim regarding her allegations.Â  Counsel also thoroughly cross-examined
  Dr. Jordan concerning her counseling sessions with the victim and her ultimate
  diagnosis.Â  Moreover, the victimâ€™s disclosure of the sexual abuse was
  corroborated by several other witnesses.Â  Therefore, we conclude the PCR judge
  erred in finding that counselâ€™s failure to interview the victim prior to trial
  constituted a basis for his decision that counsel was ineffective.
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, we conclude the PCR judge erred in granting Lorenzenâ€™s application
  for post-conviction relief.Â  Because none of the alleged errors are meritorious,
  we hold the PCR judge incorrectly relied on Nance in finding that the
  cumulative effect of these alleged errors established a claim of ineffective assistance
  of counsel.[3]Â 
  Accordingly, we reverse the order of the PCR judge.
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â Â  The solicitor sought a sentence of life in prison
  without the possibility of parole pursuant to section 17-25-25 of the South
  Carolina Code based on Lorenzenâ€™s prior conviction for armed robbery.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(A)(1), (C)(1) (2003 & Supp. 2007) (statute
  permitting the State to seek a sentence of life without the possibility of
  parole if the person has one or more prior convictions for a â€œmost serious
  offense,â€ which includes the offense of armed robbery).
[2]Â Â  In Nance, the defendant was convicted and
  received a sentence of death for murder, first-degree CSC, assault and battery
  with intent to kill, first-degree burglary, and armed robbery.Â  After the
  circuit court denied Nanceâ€™s application for post-conviction relief, he
  petitioned for certiorari.Â  This Court granted certiorari and reversed the PCR
  judgeâ€™s order on the ground Nanceâ€™s trial counsel was ineffective in that he
  failed to challenge the prosecutionâ€™s case against Nance.Â  The United States
  Supreme Court vacated this Courtâ€™s opinion and remanded the case for
  consideration in light of Florida v. Nixon, 543 U.S. 175 (2004).Â  Ozmint v. Nance, 543 U.S. 1043 (2005).
Pursuant
  to the Supreme Courtâ€™s mandate, this Court found the case represented â€œone of
  the rare cases where counsel â€˜entirely fails to subject the prosecutionâ€™s case
  to meaningful adversarial testing.â€™Â  Moreover, counsel did not act as an
  adversary to the prosecutionâ€™s case, but instead helped to bolster the case against his client.â€Â  Nance v. Frederick, 367 S.C. 547, 553, 626 S.E.2d 878, 881
  (2006), cert. denied, 127 S.Ct. 131 (2006).Â  Specifically, this Court
  found Nanceâ€™s trial counsel was deficient in the following respects:Â  (1)
  counsel was taking several prescription medications during the trial which
  resulted in impaired memory, lack of sleep, and sedation; (2) counsel provided
  Nanceâ€™s expert witness with Nanceâ€™s medical records just a few hours before the
  trial; (3) during his opening statement counsel informed the jury that he was
  appointed as a public defender and did not ask for the case; (4) counsel called
  a correctional officer as a witness who testified regarding Nanceâ€™s only
  incident of misbehavior in jail; (5) counsel called Nanceâ€™s sister to testify
  without preparing her to testify and eliciting testimony that Nance was an
  abnormal child who, among other things, killed the familyâ€™s pets; and (6)
  counsel referred to Nance during closing arguments as a â€œsickâ€ man who did
  â€œsick things.â€Â Â  Based on the these deficiencies, this Court granted Nance a
  new trial.Â  The Court found â€œthere was a total breakdown in the adversarial
  processâ€ and, thus, presumed that Nance was prejudiced.Â  Id. at 555, 626
  S.E.2d at 882.
[3]Â Â  Although we recognize that whether the cumulation of several
  errors, â€œwhich by themselves are not prejudicial, would warrant relief is an
  unsettled question in South Carolinaâ€ we do not believe the facts of this case
  present an opportunity to definitively decide this question. See Green
    v. State, 351 S.C. 184, 197, 569 S.E.2d 318, 325 (2002); Simpson v.
      Moore, 367 S.C. 587, 604, 627 S.E.2d 701, 710 (2006) (citing Green and stating â€œ[w]hether several errors, which are independently found not be
  prejudicial, may cumulatively warrant relief is an unsettled question in South Carolinaâ€).

description: This is a judicial disciplinary opinion in which the Court imposed a public reprimand.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Former Sumter County Master-in-Equity Linwood S. Evans, Jr., Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26439
Submitted February 5, 2008 - Filed February 25, 2008

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


	
		
			
				Lesley M.
  Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and James G. Bogle, Jr., Senior Assistant
  Attorney General, both of Columbia, for Â Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				
				G.
  Murrell Smith, Jr., of Sumter, for respondent.Â Â  
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this judicial disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule
  502, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the
  imposition of a public reprimand.[1]Â 
  The facts as set forth in the agreement are as follows.Â   
FACTS
Respondent served as a Master-in-Equity
  for Sumter County and maintained an official Master-in-Equity bank account.Â  On
  or about January 14, 2000, respondent issued a check to himself from his
  Master-in-Equity account in the amount of $10,000.00.Â  The check was used with
  other funds to purchase a cashierâ€™s check in the amount of $25,000.00, payable
  to Peterbilt of Mississippi, dated January 14, 2000 on behalf of respondentâ€™s
  friend.Â  On or about February 8, 2000, the friend wrote a check for $10,000.00
  to respondent.Â  Respondent deposited this check into his attorney escrow IOLTA
  account on or about the same day.Â  The same day, respondent wrote a check from
  his attorney escrow account in the amount of $10,000.00 to another individual.Â 
 
Respondent represents that, shortly
  thereafter, he returned the $10,000.00 from his escrow account to his
  Master-in-Equity account.Â  ODC has verified a deposit in that amount into
  respondentâ€™s Master-in-Equity account.Â  Respondent asserts the $10,000.00 came
  from legal fees in his escrow account.Â  ODC is unable to confirm or dispute
  respondentâ€™s assertion.Â   
Respondent admits he used his official
  Master-in-Equity funds for purposes other than that for which they were
  intended.Â  The funds have been replaced.Â   
On or about September 1998, respondent
  loaned $4,000.00 from his official Master-in-Equity account to another
  individual.Â  When the individual repaid the funds with interest, respondent
  returned them to the Master-in-Equity account.Â   
Later, respondent made a second loan of
  approximately $3,500.00 from the Master-in-Equity account to the same
  individual.Â  The funds for the second loan were repaid with interest.Â   
Thereafter, in or about January 2002, an
  â€œadvanceâ€ in the amount of $3,000.00 was made to the same individual.Â  Respondent
  acknowledges approximately $3,000.00 plus interest is still outstanding and
  owed to the Master-in-Equity account.Â  Respondent further acknowledges that
  lending or advancing funds to this individual constituted the use of official
  Master-in-Equity funds for purposes other than that for which they were
  intended.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â   
LAW
By his misconduct, respondent has violated
  the following Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR:Â  Canon 1
  (judge shall uphold integrity of the judiciary); 
Canon 2 (judge shall avoid impropriety and the
    appearance of impropriety in all activities); Canon 4(A)(2) (judge shall conduct
    all extra-judicial activities so they do not demean the judicial office); and
    Canon 4(D)(1) (judge shall not engage in financial dealings that may be
    reasonably perceived to exploit judgeâ€™s judicial position).Â  Respondent admits
    his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the following
    provisions of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502,
    SCACR:Â  Rule 7(a)(1)(it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate the
    Code of Judicial Conduct); Rule 7(a)(4) (it shall be ground for discipline for
    judge to persistently perform judicial duties in an incompetent manner); and
    Rule 7(a)(9) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate Judgeâ€™s
    Oath of Office).Â  Â 
CONCLUSION 

We accept the Agreement for Discipline by
  Consent and issue a public reprimand.Â  Respondent shall neither seek nor accept
  any judicial office in this State without the express written permission of the
  Court after due notice in writing to ODC.Â  Accordingly, respondent is hereby
  reprimanded for his misconduct.Â   
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES
  and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Respondent no longer holds judicial office.Â  A public
  reprimand is the most severe sanction the Court can impose when a judge no
  longer holds judicial office.Â  See In re Oâ€™Kelley, 361 S.C. 30,
  603 S.E.2d 410 (2004); In re Gravely, 321 S.C. 235, 467 S.E.2d 924
  (1996).
